subject: Bringing an Intersectional Lens to Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention
body:
“Rarely, if ever, are any of us healed in isolation. Healing is an act of communion.” – bell hooks
 
 
 
“Rarely, if ever, are any of us healed in isolation. Healing is an act of communion.” – bell hooks
October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month. The National Resource Center on Domestic Violence has introduced the theme of 
Heal, Hold, & Center 
to recognize and address the experiences of survivors from marginalized identities, stating: “As we heal, hold, and center survivors, especially those navigating anti-Blackness and other systems of oppression, we remain grounded in the knowledge that there is 
no survivor justice without racial justice
.” 
It is estimated that about 
1 in 2 women
 have experienced intimate partner violence in their lifetime, and 1 in 5 have experienced sexual violence by an intimate partner.  These numbers alone should be disturbing, and when we look at the racial, ethnic and cultural disparities that exist, it is even more appalling. According to the 
National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey
, women who identify as Black, Hispanic, American Indian or Alaska Native, and Multiracial experience IPV at far higher rates than White and Asian women. Members of the LGBTQ+ population also have higher rates of violence.  44% of lesbian women and 61% of bisexual women have experienced rape, physical violence, and/or stalking by an intimate partner in their lifetime. These disparities have been connected to issues of 
economic insecurity, combined with isolation, racism, and discrimination
, all which impact how women from minoritized identities experience and respond to domestic violence. Cultural or religious norms, fear or mistrust of law enforcement, lack of access to culturally or linguistically appropriate support services, all fear of immigration status all may contribute to women of the global majority getting the help they need and deserve. 
Fortunately, there is a more systemic effort being put into place to prevent and address domestic violence, with the focus being on collective work that brings allies, advocates, and survivors together to make change happen. As I’ve stated before, issues of gender inequality and violence are not a women’s issue. They are an everyone issue. 
For more information on what you can do to support change, check out the 
National Resource Center on Domestic Violence
, which has curated dozens of resources focusing on specific issues and identity group’s needs. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
Ember 2024 is October 8th-10th in Denver, CO! - 
Fire Side Chat - A webinar on Ember
With generous support from our friends at the University of Colorado Denver, MSM Global and True Change Associates are leading the second annual EMBER convening, which brings together DEI professionals and social change agents to explore strategies for tackling complex systemic challenges and reignite their passion and energy. With insights from distinguished DEI leaders across various industries, we’ll explore strategies for overcoming institutional barriers and creating meaningful change together. 
DEI Ambassadors Take a Deep Dive into Exploring Systemic Racism
MSM Global Consulting’s DEI Ambassador Program is a comprehensive train-the-trainer DEI certificate program that equips individuals with the essential skills to lead impactful DEI dialogues and learning activities. 
Last month, we launched the exciting new Ambassador 2.0 pilot program, which builds on the foundation of our Ambassador Program. Ambassador 2.0 takes the DEI journey further by immersing participants in a nine-week cohort-based dialogue focused on race and racism in their respective fields. This next phase is fostering deeper reflection and action in advancing DEI efforts.
Learn more about the Ambassador program 
here
, and contact us if you would like to run this dynamic program with your organization! 
  
Culture Stew
We’ve hit 100 Episodes! 
In the first episode of Season 6, we're celebrating our 100th episode of Culture Stew. Join Maria Morukian as she talks with scholars Devin Moran and Jasmin Robinson to discuss the challenges Black women leaders face and how to balance justice work with self-care. Listen now to this powerful conversation on intersectional gender equity on your favorite podcast platform or the 
MSM Global Consulting website
! 
 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Honoring Indigenous Peoples' Day: Going Beyond Land Acknowledgement 
This Indigenous Peoples' Day takes place October 14. A common practice that has gained steam in recent years is land acknowledgement. Land acknowledgement is an attempt to recognize the Indigenous nations upon whose land an entity may occupy, and is often offered either in written or verbal form. Although land acknowledgement may be delivered with positive intent, it can also be seen as performative and can frustrate members of Indigenous communities who may be called upon to engage in the emotional labor of offering guidance and advice on such acknowledgements.  It also begs the question, what are we actively doing to recognize and respond to the actual needs of Indigenous communities who have experienced intergenerational violence and oppression throughout the history of our nation? 
The 
Native Governance Center
 offers tips for ways to go beyond land acknowledgement to engage in true advocacy for Indigenous populations. In addition to encouraging people to do their own research on the history of the Indigenous land they occupy, the Center encourages individuals and organizations to assess how they might use their resources to support Indigenous communities in terms of money, time, land/space, tuition or entry into events or activities that provide value for those communities. Discover more guidance 
here
.
A Proclamation on National Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention Month
The White House
 
October is National Domestic Violence Awareness and Prevention Month, and this year we also commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA). We encourage leaders and advocates for social change to raise awareness about the prevalence of domestic violence and to take action in supporting survivors and preventing abuse. Domestic violence impacts millions of individuals across all backgrounds, and it is our collective responsibility to foster safe and supportive environments where everyone can live free from violence and fear.
If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic violence, there are resources available to help: 
National Domestic Violence Hotline: Call 1-800-799-SAFE (7233), text "START" to 88788, or visit 
thehotline.org
 for confidential support.
RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network): Call 1-800-656-HOPE (4673) or visit 
rainn.org
 for help and resources.
Local Shelters and Support Services: Visit 
domesticshelters.org
 to find nearby shelters and services.
Learn more about this important month and how you can take action by reading 
the official proclamation.
 
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com

CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
Celebrating Artistic Powerhouses: Natalia Hernandez, Carolyn Castaño, and Carmen Linares 
In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, we highlight three remarkable women shaping the landscape of art, literature, and music. From Natalia Hernandez’s queer fantasy novels set in Latin American-inspired worlds, to Carolyn Castaño’s award-winning mixed-media artistry, and Carmen Linares’ legendary flamenco performances, these Hispanic creators are leaving an indelible mark on contemporary culture while proudly representing their heritage.
 
Natalia Hernandez
 -Author - Natalia Hernandez is the author of acclaimed fantasy book, The Name Bearer, is described as “a story of magia, warrior women, found family and love - and not accepting who you are told to be, but embracing who you are destined to become.” Hernandez identifies as an Indigenous, Latinx, queer book nerd, and Third Culture Kid who has lived all over the globe.  Her work centers queer identities and strong women of color, and Latin American culture.
 
 
Carolyn Castaño
 -Artist -Carolyn Castaño is a Los Angeles-based artist whose work spans painting, drawing, video, and mixed-media installations. A recipient of prestigious awards like the Joan Mitchell Foundation Grant and the California Community Foundation Getty Fellow Grant, her work has been showcased in notable exhibitions, including the Venice Biennale and LACMA. Currently, she is an Assistant Professor of Painting and Drawing at Long Beach City College.
 
Carmen Linares
 - Musician - Carmen Linares, a living legend of 
flamenco
, has earned a prominent place in Spanish musical culture, alongside icons like Tomatito and Paco de Lucía. With a career spanning over 40 years, Linares has performed internationally and collaborated with renowned artists. Her discography includes over 30 titles, and she recently celebrated her milestone project, Cantaora: 40 years of flamenco. Linares' achievements have been recognized with numerous awards, including the 2022 Princess of Asturias Award and the 2023 Latin Grammy Award.

subject: Are you ready for the changes to the Worker’s Protection Act?
body:
Employers will have additional responsibility to take “reasonable steps” to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace from 26th October.
 
 
Dear colleagues,
Employers will have additional responsibility to take “reasonable steps” to prevent sexual harassment in the workplace from 26
th
 October. This includes engaging in training, process and policy reviews, third-party facing mechanisms, and appropriate reporting processes.
 
Failing to actively prevent sexual harassment in the workplace will result in a 25% increased financial compensation for victims in cases taken to Employment Tribunal.
  
Why is this sexual harassment in the workplace a timely topic?
I’m sure we can all agree that sexual harassment has no place in life full stop, let alone in the workplace.
But it happens. Far too often.
 
A 
new report by McKinsey and LeanIn
 shows that sexual harassment is just as prevalent now, in 2024, than in 2018.
 
In 2018, 35 percent of women reported experiencing at least one form of 
sexual harassment 
in the workplace, according to the report, published this week. This year, that portion is 37 percent. Of course, people of all genders experience sexual harassment, and the 
changes to the Worker’s Protection Act
 (WPA) equally covers all people regardless of gender.
We can also guarantee that there are far more experiences of sexual harassment than those we see through these statistics. A lack of psychological safety to speak out, a lack of understanding of what constitutes sexual harassment, and internalised guilt all affect reporting rates and should be taken seriously.
Our work shows consistently that any workplace inclusion issue such as micro aggressions, pay inequality, or in this case, sexual harassment, tends to happen more frequently to people in minoritised groups.
  
So what should you do?
 
As employers, leaders, and practitioners it is important that you prepare for the changes to the WPA, and fulfil the responsibility to take ‘reasonable steps’ to prevent sexual harassment.
Here are 5 recommendations to get you started:
 
Understand: 
Run psychologically safe focus groups and interviews to learn more about employees’ experiences to inform approaches. Whether traditional focus groups or anonymised digital ones, listening to your colleagues is important and imperative.
 
Raise awareness:
 Run sessions on the topic to raise colleague awareness of what sexual harassment is, and the governance and support available. A participant at one of our recent Anti-Sexual Harassment webinars said, "
The managing directors contacted me after 5 mins of the session to tell me they were not expecting such a high quality of materials and delivery from the facilitators. TOP NOTCH!" 
 
Strengthen governance:
 review, update and improve existing policies on sexual harassment (and surrounding policies on bullying and harassment, ethics and employee conduct); taking into account the understanding and application of policies. For example you may want to train a team of ambassadors or support staff to become points of contact on the topic of sexual harassment in the workplace
 
Take the 
right
 action:
 Work with and lead steering groups or committees to tailor a bespoke response to the WPA changes; complete with an action plan and RACI models
 
Align outcomes:
 organisations that link values and behaviours to their performance management outcomes, see quicker results and culture change. Besides policy change, consider the range of implications (whether that be pay related, training, through to termination) that can and should be taken and the rigor that governs this.
Get in touch
 to learn more, we’d love to support you in implementing responses to the upcoming changes and increased responsibilities you hold in your workplaces. Clients have described our work in this space as “thought-provoking”, “effective”, “powerful”, and “empowering”. We bring expertise, experience, and openness to create spaces for meaningful dialogue, concrete plans, and reassurance for colleagues and key stakeholders alike.
If you have a story to share please get in touch via email at 
info@included.com
. By valuing and supporting individuals, your organisation can better your people’s experiences at work and unlock the full potential of your workforce.
 
 
More than pay: fairness and inclusion for lasting impact
Join 
Included
 and Fair Pay Innovation Lab for this insightful session exploring how you can move beyond pay equity to create truly inclusive workplaces.
The session wraps up with a Q&A where you can raise questions and share challenges. If time permits, optional Breakout Discussions will explore topics like measuring EDI impact, inclusive leadership, and actionable ways to integrate inclusion into everyday work.

The Business Case for Diversity: A Path to Your Organization's Success
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Tamara!
Here is this week's DEI+ Newsletter:
Imagine the following situation:
A mid-sized company, Horizon Tech, is struggling with employee turnover and stagnating innovation.
Leadership holds a meeting to discuss potential solutions, but the conversation quickly shifts to complaints about communication breakdowns and a lack of fresh ideas.
Then, a junior team member speaks up, suggesting that their workforce lacks diversity and, as a result, a variety of perspectives.
The silence that follows speaks volumes. It’s a truth that the company has been avoiding.
How can they expect innovation when nearly all their employees come from similar backgrounds and think in the same ways?
 
 
The Current Environment
In recent years, the business case for diversity has gained significant traction, with numerous studies demonstrating the tangible benefits of diverse, equitable, and inclusive workplaces.
However, despite the clear advantages, the current climate around diversity is met with increasing pushback.
Some organizations and individuals question the need for ongoing diversity efforts, labeling them as superficial or burdensome.
This resistance often stems from misunderstandings or fears about the impact of these changes on existing workplace dynamics.  
 
Nonetheless, it's critical to address these concerns head-on, as the long-term success and competitiveness of your organization, especially with the upcoming demographic changes, will depend on the successful implementation of your diversity initiatives.  
 
 
 
The ROI of Diversity 
In today's competitive business environment, the return on investment (ROI) of diversity initiatives is undeniable. Organizations that embrace diversity and foster inclusive workplaces experience a range of measurable benefits. Below are just a few of them.
 
1. Impact on Innovation and Creativity 
Diverse teams generate diverse perspectives which can lead to more creative solutions.
Research consistently shows that companies with diverse workforces are more innovative. A 2018 study by Boston Consulting Group (BCG) found that organizations with higher levels of diversity in management reported 19% higher innovation revenue than those with lower levels.
How does this work in practice?
When employees from diverse backgrounds—whether it be race, gender, age, or cultural experiences—come together, they approach problems from multiple angles.
These fresh perspectives help to challenge prevailing assumptions and generate ideas that might not have emerged in a homogenous team.  
 
2. Impact on Decision Making  
Diversity not only fosters creativity but also enhances decision-making.
When decisions are made by groups that lack diversity, there’s a risk of “groupthink,” where everyone shares the same views and biases.
In contrast, a more diverse group will challenge each other’s perspectives, leading to more thorough and balanced decisions. 
 
A 2017 study by 
Cloverpop
 supports this notion. Results showed that diverse and inclusive teams make better business decisions up to 87% of the time.  
 
 
3. Access to a Broader Talent Pool 
Companies that prioritize diversity are more attractive to top talent.
The workforce is becoming increasingly more diverse, and employees are looking for companies that reflect their values.  
 
According to 
Glassdoor
, 67% of job seekers consider diversity an important factor when evaluating companies and job offers.  
 
By fostering a diverse environment, businesses can attract a wider talent pool, including individuals who may bring unique skills and perspectives that are vital in today’s market. In a competitive talent market, failing to prioritize diversity can lead to a loss of qualified candidates to competitors who actively promote a diverse workforce.
 
4. Enhanced Brand Reputation and Market Reach 
A diverse workforce is not just a strength internally but also externally.
Companies that visibly prioritize diversity are more likely to build positive brand reputations. In fact, consumers are increasingly holding businesses accountable for their social values, including how they treat their employees and promote inclusion. 
 
According to a report by the 
Harvard Business Review
, companies with diverse leadership are perceived as more socially responsible and innovative by consumers.  
 
This perception can translate into greater customer loyalty and trust. Additionally, a diverse team can better understand and cater to a diverse customer base, ensuring that products and services meet the needs of a wide range of consumers.
Horizon Tech, for example, would be better positioned to expand into new markets if they had a workforce that mirrors their diverse customer base. By hiring people with different social and cultural backgrounds, they would gain insights into how to tailor their products and marketing strategies to new audiences, ensuring relevance and authenticity. 
 
Measuring the ROI: What is Your Data Showing? 
One of the concerns we frequently hear from companies trying to implement diversity initiatives is how to measure the return on investment of such initiatives.
While the benefits of diversity are clear, some leaders remain skeptical about the financial impact.
The good news there I plenty of data supporting the positive financial outcomes of diverse organizations.
A McKinsey report, for example, found that companies in the top quartile for racial and ethnic diversity were 35% more likely to have financial returns above their respective national industry medians. Similarly, gender-diverse companies were 21% more likely to outperform their peers financially.  
 
These figures highlight that diversity isn’t just good for company culture—it’s good for the bottom line. 
 
To measure success, organizations should establish clear metrics, such as diversity in hiring, retention rates, employee satisfaction, representation at leadership levels, and others.
Regular surveys, feedback loops, and data analysis help pinpoint areas for improvement and demonstrate ROI, ensuring DEI initiatives remain impactful and aligned with business goals. 
 
DEI+: A Business Imperative 
For companies like Horizon Tech, integrating diversity and inclusion into the heart of their business strategy isn’t just about social responsibility—it’s about ensuring long-term success and gaining a competitive advantage.
From fostering innovation and better decision-making to attracting top talent to enhanced market reach, the benefits of a diverse workforce are undeniable.  
 
It’s time to move beyond seeing diversity as a checkbox and embrace it as a fundamental driver of business success. By doing so, companies will not only benefit from increased engagement, innovation, and profitability but also contribute to a more inclusive, equitable world. 
 
 
Feel free to forward this newsletter to those you think might benefit and encourage them to 
SUBSCRIBE
.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers) 
Global DEI+ Consultant and Strategist

subject: Advancing and Amplifying Gender Equity for Global Prosperity
body:
First of all, DEI programs are not the cause of societal backlash and increasing polarization.
 
 
 
News flash! The more women we see in leadership positions, the more our teams, organizations, and societies thrive. 
Gender equity leads to economic growth and development
: Nations with higher levels of gender equity and female economic participation have higher growth, more favorable development outcomes, and lower income inequality.
Psychological research shows that women leaders improve organizations
: Decades of research show that women demonstrate more transformative leadership styles, and rank better than or equal to men in almost every trait relevant to leadership. Teams are more collaborative, and organizations are seen as more equitable and less prone to stereotypes. 
More women in leadership leads to greater financial success
: Companies with more women in leadership positions financially outperform those with fewer, and top-performing organizations are accelerating more women leaders. 
So why is progress toward gender equity still so damn slow? And why, oh why, is there still such backlash, bias, and castigation of women in positions of power? 
Women continue to earn less while being expected to do more
: Globally, women in the labor market earn 23% less than men, and spend 3 times as many hours in unpaid domestic and care work. 
The pace of parity is abysmally slow
: With only 27 nations currently led by women, gender equality in the highest positions of power will not be reached for another 130 years.
Women are not adequately represented in the leadership pipeline
: Although women are outpacing men in terms of advanced education and training, on average they make up only 23% of high-potential employees even at top-performing organizations. 
Although this has been a primary issue for generations, gender equity issues are even more prominent right now, with US states rolling back reproductive rights for women, increased attacks on gender nonbinary and transgender folks, efforts to exclude trans women from participating in athletics, and the ongoing struggle for representation and pay equity for women everywhere. Not to mention the nation’s first presidential candidate who is a Black and South Asian woman!
Until we as a society treat this as an EVERYONE issue, not just a women’s issue, we will not be able to make adequate progress toward gender equity, meaning we won’t see the economic, cultural, and technological gains that come with women leading. This issue of the newsletter will provide some additional insights and resources for amplifying the voices of women and femme-identifying individuals and strengthening systems to advance opportunities for people of all genders. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
MSM at Washington and Lee University 
Last month, our incredible facilitators Gwen Crider and Devin Moran traveled to Lexington, VA to meet with incoming law students at Washington and Lee University. During the 4-hour program, students explored core DEI concepts, reflected on their identities, and participated in activities designed to foster empathy and understanding. The session left everyone inspired and eager to continue the important work of creating a more inclusive campus community. 
MSM Team in Phoenix 
Last week, Jasmin Robinson and Maria Morukian traveled to Phoenix, AZ to 
facilitate our highly regarded DEI Ambassador Program with The Association for Animal Welfare Advancement. The Ambassador program provides each cohort of DEI champions with the opportunity to build awareness of concepts of DEI, reflect on their own identities and potential biases, and build skills to facilitate dialogues on DEI issues and strategically advance diversity, equity, and inclusion in their respective organizations. If your organization is interested in building internal capacity for DEI initiatives, contact us for more information on our highly sought-after Ambassador program at 
info@msmglobalconsulting.com
! 
New Course Offerings
Pushing Past the DEI “Wall”: Endurance Strategies to Go the Distance 
Being a champion for DEI is all about endurance. Even the most well-trained endurance runners have found themselves hitting the “wall,” when their energy suddenly bottoms out and they feel like they’ve run headfirst into a brick building. After repeated attempts to make progress for DEI only to face inertia, ambivalence, and hostility, anyone involved in DEI efforts (e.g. leaders, trainers, talent development professionals, DEI practitioners) may find themselves feeling exhausted by what feel like insurmountable odds. How can we push past the “wall,” to surge our DEI efforts forward in the moments of greatest adversity, without causing damage to ourselves and others? This session will explore strategies to bring an endurance mindset and regimen to DEI, and equip individuals with the tools to develop the physical, mental, and emotional stamina to continue to make progress even when we hit the wall.
Learn more about this program, and others, with our Course Catalog on the MSM Global Consulting website.
  
Culture Stew
Welcome to Season Six of the Culture Stew Podcast!
This season, we are experimenting with some new approaches and focusing on a central theme, exploring gender equity from an intersectional perspective, and shifting the focus from deficit-based narratives to stories of strength, creativity, and resilience. Gender inclusion and equity is a universal issue, and with reproductive rights under attack and the ongoing fight for trans and non-binary inclusion, these discussions are more critical than ever. We’re excited to welcome a lineup of inspiring guests, from those amplifying marginalized voices in literature to advocates for reproductive rights of incarcerated women. The first episode comes out today! Listen 
here
!
 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Ember: A Fireside Chat
We are thrilled to announce the second annual Ember gathering, a unique multi-day experience designed by and for DEI change agents and practitioners dedicated to tackling the most complex challenges we face in our field. The 2024 program will be hosted at the University of Colorado Denver campus October 8th - 10th 2024.  
To find out more, listen to our recent “fireside chat” with previous participants and panelists who share insights on the value of this unique program. Join us as we build a community committed to advancing lasting systemic change for equity and inclusion.
Registration for Ember is still open but ends October 2nd so register today! Subscribers to the MSM Global newsletter are eligible for a 10% discount.
Contact us for more details at 
info@msmglobalconsulting.com
.
Ember 
Registration Link
DDI Global Leadership Forecast 2023
Development Dimensions International
 (DDI)’s 2023 Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Report highlights critical statistics about the underrepresentation of women in leadership.  DDI’s research found that while women are entering the workforce in strong numbers, they still face barriers in advancing into leadership positions. 
Research reveals a strong link between women in leadership and company performance. Top-performing companies still only have 29% of female representation in leadership positions, and underperforming firms lag considerably at 23%. Moreover, these underperforming companies have seen their share of women leaders drop since 2020. High-performing companies are more likely to develop women for leadership roles, yet women still represent just 23% of high-potential leadership pools. Companies with robust leadership pipelines tend to include more women, with 28% in high-potential pools compared to 18% in firms with weaker bench strength.
We are not shocked by these numbers. We know them. We live them. We must change them and we need to stop ignoring women. This article paints a clear picture. 
Measuring Inclusion by Paolo Gaudiano
 
Releasing on 9/24/24, Measuring Inclusion offers a fresh, data-driven approach to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI), emphasizing the importance of measuring inclusion to boost organizational performance and employee satisfaction without backlash. Featuring step-by-step guidance, real-world case studies, and tools to quantify the financial ROI of DEI efforts, this book provides practical strategies to make organizations more inclusive and successful. 
Join MSM Global’s CEO Maria Morukian, who will share the stage with author Paolo Gaudiano at an upcoming Book Launch Festival on September 23rd to learn more about Measuring Inclusion and the book’s implications for DEI practitioners. 
  
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com
 TODAY! 
CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
 
 
Invisible Women: Exposing Data Bias in a World Designed for Men
 
Invisible Women exposes the pervasive gender bias in everyday life, revealing how a world designed by and for men systematically overlooks women. Through case studies and research, Caroline Criado Perez highlights the gender data gap and its profound impact on women's health, safety, and well-being. This powerful book is a rallying cry for change, challenging readers to see the world through a more inclusive lens.
Unbecoming
 
In a near-future America where abortions are illegal, Muslim teens Laylah and Noor fight for reproductive rights by creating an underground abortion guide in Texas. While both are passionate about their mission, Laylah's urgency is tied to a painful secret involving their mosque and a local politician. Despite growing dangers, the two best friends remain determined to change the world together. 
 
About MSM Global
We specialize in organizational culture change by empowering organizations to achieve greater success through embracing equity, diversity and inclusivity. We provide a holistic approach to organizational development, team capacity building, and leadership development. Let us know what would be helpful for you in this newsletter.

subject: $1.24 billion as European technology comes of age
body:
Today we’re announcing two funds totalling $1.24 billion to support Europe’s most gamechanging founders.
 
 
$1.24 billion as European technology comes of age
  
Our largest ever fundraise for Europe’s gamechangers
 
 
Today we’re announcing two funds totalling $1.24 billion to support Europe’s most gamechanging founders. The final number represents a more than 50 per cent increase on Atomico V, our previous $820 million fund.
Atomico was founded with the vision that exceptional companies can come from anywhere. Since inception we’ve partnered with founders from series A, expanding to include growth investments in 2011. This approach is now formalised under dedicated venture and growth funds, with a specialised team for each stage of maturity.
Our new funds come as the $3 trillion European technology ecosystem begins to rival its global counterparts. Europe now captures close to 30 per cent of global early stage funding and is 
creating more new companies
 than any other region.
 
Niklas Zennström, founder and CEO of Atomico, said: “European technology is coming of age. Meeting this opportunity requires ambition, hustle and commitment from founders, who need investors with the experience and perspective to see beyond market cycles.”
Read more about the new funds and our approach, 
here
.
 
It’s that time of year again - the State of European Tech is back for 2024!
This year will mark a special anniversary for the State of European Tech report, which has charted the growth and development of the ecosystem for 10 years. 
We want to hear your views on tech in Europe in 2024, your thoughts about the sector and how it’s evolved in the past decade.   
To make your voice heard, fill in the new and improved streamlined survey now
. 
This year, it’s easier than ever to have your say. It only takes a few  minutes, and participants have a chance of winning a ticket to Slush, ​​the most founder-focused event and largest gathering of VC in the world.

, the Swedish healtech cofounded by Spotify’s Daniel Ek, 
launched
 its first UK clinic. Neko is using AI to revolutionise preventative healthcare, and arrives in London on the back of a strong first year of operations in Stockholm.

Lakera
. You can read Lakera’s landmark report on enterprise readiness for GenAI 
here
.

, which harnesses AI to improve drug discovery for the treatment of rare diseases,

 $47 million in a Series C round led by Atomico. This is an exciting time for Healx, who will start Phase 2 clinical trials for its lead program having recently received clearance from the US Food & Drug Administration.
We’re delighted to see Danish AI co-pilot for healthcare 
Corti
 
announce
 record US growth and three new partnerships. Corti’s platform now supports 100,000+ daily patient interactions in the US.
Translations platform
 
DeepL
 
launched a new Large Language Model which outperforms Google Translate and ChatGPT. This comes off the back of the company’s latest 
funding round

subject: Addressing Racism, Extremism, and Diversity in Turbulent Times
body:
In the wake of tragic events and rise of divisive rhetoric spurred on across the UK, we must address social unrest and promote EDI in the aftermath.
 
 
Dear colleagues,
In the wake of tragic events and the rise of divisive rhetoric spurred on across England and Northern Ireland 
by 
racist, Islamophobic supporters of 
the far-right
, we must address social unrest and promote equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI) in the aftermath. 
There is no doubt that you yourself, or your colleagues might be feeling uneasy, perhaps still unsafe, whether that be for themselves, their family members and friends, or perhaps for their children about to return to school. We in the corporate world must address this crisis and the impact it has on our employees, culture, on performance and productivity too, as well as the ripple effect on the wider world. 
Here are five ways we can influence within our organisation, briefly noted here:
Facilitate dialogue and reconciliation
 - create forums for open and honest conversations; foster mutual understanding and healing. It’s important to have confident, informed facilitators for these conversations, otherwise they may do more damage than good.
 
Identify and address systemic inequities
 - from misinformation and language to biases in organisational policies, processes and practices; use a data-driven approach to target the most impactful levers
 
Develop a comprehensive EDI Strategy
 – one that is embedded across the business strategy and employee experience, with inclusion as a core value; and accountability and measures across all levels 
 
Strengthen community partnerships
 - collaborate with local organisations and community leaders; amplify diverse voices and perspectives
 
Invest in education and awareness
 - provide EDI training for employees at all levels; encourage ongoing learning and accountability with campaigns to promote understanding 
 
From keynotes and fireside chats to multi-month inclusive leadership programmes, data diagnostics and EDI strategy design and implementation, we can help you gain buy-in for inclusive change, tailored to all levels of the organisation.
With regards to 
investing in education and awareness
, if you are 
hoping to get certified in EDI and learn more as a practitioner, our 
Diversity and Inclusion in the Workplace
 
8-week course may be of interest to you! 
By completing this course, which starts on 12 September, you will:
 
• Enhance your professional credentials with a prestigious certification
• Gain invaluable tools to drive meaningful change
• Improve team dynamics and ensure legal compliance
 
This certification course aims to provide a thorough understanding of the main components of diversity, equity, equality, inclusion and belonging. Devised and delivered by two leading D&I organisations in the UK & Ireland, 
Included
 and Legal Island.
Engage in a dynamic learning experience with expert-led online lectures, insightful readings, and practical assignments. Explore key concepts and strategies to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in your workplace.
Secure your spot now by 
enrolling here
.
 
This course is suited for business leaders, HR professionals and passionate DEI advocates who are dedicated to building inclusive cultures within their organisations.
It will also suit organisations with a newly created D&I post wanting to access immediately relevant knowledge, contacts and networks. 
If we are working with you this month, feel free to ask us directly about the topics above, and if you have a story to share please get in touch via email at 
info@included.com
. By valuing and supporting individuals, your organisation can better your people’s experiences at work and unlock the full potential of your workforce.

subject: The Importance of the “E” in DEI
body:
First of all, DEI programs are not the cause of societal backlash and increasing polarization.
 
 
 
Recently, the Society for Human Resource Management, SHRM, announced it would no longer use the word “equity” and instead focus on Inclusion and Diversity. 
SHRM’s rationale for eradicating the term equity was to address the "
current shortcomings of DE&I programs, which have led to societal backlash and increasing polarization.
” SHRM further argued that the terms inclusion and diversity are more easily understood by employees than the concept of equity. 
First of all, DEI programs are not the cause of societal backlash and increasing polarization. Social change movements inevitably face backlash and resistance when attempting to challenge the status quo and rebalance power structures, and our nation has been facing increasing ideological polarization for decades. Even the term “DEI” has become a target of the culture war, leveraged as a thinly veiled insult to dismiss the skills, experience, and contributions of people from marginalized identities. By claiming that anyone who is a person of color, women, or member of the LGBTQ+ community is a “DEI hire” indicates that they were chosen only because of their identity and not because of their qualifications, which in the words of my colleague Dan Egol is “
Basic Human Nonsense.
”  
Secondly, equity is not a confusing term unless we make it so. Equity is often misrepresented as “reverse discrimination” or preferential treatment, rather than setting policies and practices that ensure that everyone has what they need to contribute and succeed. Equity requires us to acknowledge that there are systemic imbalances in our society that benefit some at the expense of others. In her book, 
Equity
, Minal Bopaiah states, “Centering people who need and deserve better outcomes means being aware of their historical and/or current exploitation and then examining how our current systems might be perpetuating that exploitation.”  When we create policies that center the experiences and needs of those who have been most adversely impacted by our inequitable systems, everyone stands to benefit.  
Also, equitable practices don’t need to be overwhelming, costly, or time consuming. For instance, developing 
parental leave policies
 that prioritize the health and wellness of 
parents of all kinds
 can lead to better health and wellness as well as higher levels of engagement among all employees who become parents and guardians.  
The “E” is important because it encourages us to tap into our collective imagination, to explore possibilities that unleash us from outdated patterns of thinking and systemic norms that limit our potential. Rather than dropping it from the lexicon, we should reiterate the benefits of equity and make equitable practices easy to apply. 
 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting

Workplace Equity: The "E" in DEI and Why It Matters 
Workplace equity is crucial for creating fair and productive environments, yet only 28% of employees feel their workplace is equitable. Gallup defines equity as fair treatment, access, and advancement for all, considering historical and sociopolitical factors. Equity goes beyond diversity and inclusion by addressing issues like pay fairness, opportunities for advancement, and daily work experiences. Organizations should integrate equity into their core values, conduct equity audits, and ensure policies are fair in practice, not just on paper, to foster an inclusive culture.
 
Equity: How to Design Organizations Where Everyone Thrive
s 
"Equity" is a fast and engaging read that helps leaders create more inclusive organizations using human-centered design and behavior change principles. Minal Bopaiah emphasizes the critical role of equity in leveraging differences for greater impact, offering real-world examples of systemic bias awareness and policy crafting. The book illustrates how equity can be embedded into core business functions, expanding DEI beyond HR initiatives. Filled with humor and pragmatism, "Equity" serves as a guidebook for leaders seeking effective organizational change.

subject: Religion, ethics and decision making: why do Christians vote for Trump?
body:
Harris has hit the ground running injecting pace and energy into the US presidential election race
 
 
Dear colleagues,
 
Harris has hit the ground running injecting pace and energy into the US presidential election race, but a second Trump Presidency is still, with 100 days to go, a likely outcome according to a number of polls.
Much has been made of the evangelical Christians who form an important part of Trump’s base. For some on the outside looking in there is an incompatibility between the assumed values of the religious right and their enthusiastic endorsement of Trump whose ‘sins’ are regularly paraded across social media and have recently become a matter of law.
 
To be clear, all leaders are flawed. In order to excel in certain areas, others are neglected. This would be true of Mother Theresa, Tony Blair and Oprah Winfrey. However, and whatever your politics, it is disturbing that a convicted felon could be the World’s Commander in Chief.
 
The 78-year-old Trump is the first former president in US history to be criminally convicted, having been found guilty of falsifying business records. A few weeks later, the US Supreme Court ruled he had partial immunity in perhaps the most serious case he faces - that he tried to overturn the 2020 election result.
 
Currently, half of the voting public might vote for him. Enthusiastically, in many cases.
 
Making Choices
In any decision-making scenario, frameworks can be helpful. With our clients around the world we regularly use decision-making models such as Vroom-Yetton decision-making models and the RACI model. However, religion offers billions of people their most tried and tested decision-making framework.
Whilst we can expect businesses to try and identify ‘rational’ frameworks to support decision making, voting and political allegiance is intensely personal and religion can be helpful to many people by providing a set of values and norms to help when making big choices.
 
Last week Trump spoke at a rally for Christian republicans in Florida receiving a warm welcome. He describes himself as a non-denominational Christian and has galvanised a strong contingent of evangelical Christians behind him, in part due to his unequivocal stance on conservative Christian issues such as abortion. For many Christians on the right this alone is a vote winner. For them the role Trump played in overturning the 1973 supreme court ruling on Roe V Wade, which generally protected the right to an abortion, only reinforces his credentials, as a pro-Christian leader.
And yet, for many people of faith in America and around the world those same positions, and the combination of Trump’s bombastic, racist and misogynistic language and actions make his candidacy incompatible with their faith.
 
Diverse views in a ‘broad church’
For those of us with no religion the inconsistent views held by adherents to the great religions can undermine their inherent value. How can one religion both endorse and repudiate the actions of a former, and possible future president?
 
Perhaps the ability for such a diverse range of views on politics, and many other issues, is a lesson to those of us outside the tent of religious observance that it is possible to vehemently disagree with someone and still call them family.
 
Creating space for difficult conversations
Businesses are institutions that people can trust in. Employees are crying out for employers to create spaces where we can have difficult conversations about social issues within the frameworks of civility that are inherent to mature businesses.
The Edelman Trust barometer highlights how distrust breeds polarisation with only 20% of respondents willing to live near or have as a co-worker someone who disagreed with their point of view. We know that the diversity of the workplace means that we are more likely to come into contact with diverse viewpoints in the workplace than we are in our self-selected social networks.
Can workplaces use the trusted environments bound by norms of civility and restraint to create safe spaces for difficult conversations on social and political issues? We think so, and whilst the church with its history of schisms might not be the perfect model it is the original ‘broad church’.
What can we take from its example?
If we are working with you this month, feel free to ask us directly about these topics, and if you have a story to share please get in touch via email at

body:
Wednesday, July 24, 2024
4 pm GMT |8 am PST | 10 am CST | 12 pm EST)
 
 
Dear Tamara,
 
Is your organization looking to deepen existing programs or recommitting to inclusion? Then this webinar is for you. It will provide crucial insights and practical strategies to help you on the journey to successful, sustainable organizational culture transformation.
 
'No Overnight Successes: Why You Need To Commit To Inclusion' will provide invaluable insights whether you have established DE&I programs or are just embarking on your inclusion journey. We'll explore:
The long-term commitment required for meaningful change.
Understanding cultural transformation processes.
Tackling systemic issues effectively.
Sustaining momentum towards DE&I goals.
Personal growth in inclusion leadership.
Whether you're looking to deepen existing initiatives or kickstart new ones, this webinar offers practical strategies for creating sustainable, measurable impact.
 
Don't miss this opportunity to engage in a critical conversation about authentic, organization-wide commitment to inclusion. Join us live and contribute to making workplaces that truly work for everyone.

subject: Upcoming Webinar - No Overnight Successes: Why You Need to Commit to Inclusion
body:
Wednesday, July 24, 2024
4 pm GMT |8 am PST | 10 am CST | 12 pm EST)
 
 
Dear Tamara,
 
We are excited to invite you to our upcoming interactive webinar designed to guide inclusive leaders through the long-term commitments required to create meaningful and measurable change within their organizations.
 
Webinar Details:
Date:
 Wednesday, July 24, 2024
Time:
 4 PM BST, 11 AM EDT, 10 AM CDT, 8 AM PDT
REGISTER HERE
 
In today’s rapidly evolving business landscape, the need for authentic engagement with Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DE&I) has never been more critical. Whether your organization is looking to deepen existing DE&I programs or is newly recommitting to inclusion, this workshop will provide crucial insights and practical strategies for fostering a successful and sustainable organizational culture transformation.
 
What You Will Learn:
The Necessity of Long-Term Inclusion Initiatives:
 Why businesses must be prepared for the long haul.
Cultural Change Dynamics:
 Understanding the nature and pace of cultural transformation.
Addressing Systemic Issues:
 Unraveling complexities and seizing opportunities.
Sustaining Momentum:
 Keeping morale high toward achieving long-term DE&I goals.
Personal Inclusion Journey:
 Owning and advancing your role in fostering inclusion.
Join us live for this imperative conversation and gain valuable knowledge that will empower you to drive impactful change within your organization. Together, let's work towards creating workplaces where everyone can thrive.
 
REGISTER HERE
 
We look forward to your participation!

subject: Embracing Emergence: How to Bring a Liberatory Mindset to Our Life and Work
body:
Recently, I’ve been toying with the concept of emergence.
 
 
 
Recently, I’ve been reflecting on the concept of emergence.
Emergence is defined as a process of coming into view, or coming into being.  Emergence can also be defined as something that is exposed after being concealed. The word itself is derived from the Latin term 
emergere
, which translates to “bring to light.”   
Ida B. Wells famously said, “The way to right wrongs is to turn the light of truth upon them.” Everywhere I turn, I see this concept of emergence in play. We are in a time when so many inequitable systems have been exposed to the light. The mere act of calling these truths to the surface is an act of liberation. We are freeing ourselves from the social conditioning that has held us captive in thinking there is no alternative way to be. What we pay attention to becomes more prominent in our individual and collective lives. 
In her seminal work, 
Emergent Strategy: Shaping Change, Changing Worlds
,
 adriene maree brown urges us to imagine “new worlds that transition ideologies and norms, so that no one sees Black people as murderers, or Brown people as terrorists and aliens, but all of us as potential cultural and economic innovators.” 
Thus, the concept of emergence is one that engages us all as collective ideators, as collaborators of the future state that is centered in a deep love for all of humanity and a profound respect for the natural environment. 
 
This language may speak to some and may seem utterly “woo-woo” to others, but let’s look at it in practice. 
 
The challenges we face in our communities, organizations, and societies tend to be complex, nuanced, and difficult to untangle. They require collective efforts, in which 1) everyone is invested in the creation of a shared vision for the future, and 2) they know what to do individually to help manifest that future vision. For many of us who have committed ourselves to social change and DEI work, we don’t always do a great job with either or both of these key elements. We get lost in the reactive nature of the work, or we judge those who do not immediately jump on board with our vision of the future state or do not know how to individually contribute to that future state through their own actions. We burn ourselves out trying to preach at others, or we rely on one charismatic leader who then gets burnt out and when they leave, we stagnate. 
 
Emergence cannot just happen at the beginning of a change movement, when all of a sudden we have a moment of enlightenment. Emergence must be carried through every stage of the journey. For me personally, I think it starts with more gentleness. By that I mean being more gentle with myself and celebrating the moments when I need to downshift to a slower pace. It means being gentle with others who may struggle to see themselves reflected in the work of social change, who have missteps, who inadvertently cause harm. Nobody wants to be berated for saying or doing something they didn’t know would hurt others. 
What emerges and gains prominence in our lives is based on what we call forth and what we choose to see.  I encourage all of us committed to a more just society and more human-centered organizations to be intentional about what we call forth in our institutions as well as what we call forth within ourselves. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
EMBER: Igniting and Sustaining a Community of Equity Practitioners -  Registration is OPEN
Our mission at EMBER is to build a vibrant, purpose-driven community of aspiring and experienced DEI practitioners. Through deep self-reflection, peer coaching, and research-based DEI practices, we aim to equip participants with the tools and knowledge to create lasting change in their organizations.
Learn more and register now: 
Registration: 2024 Ember - MSM Global Consulting 
July 23rd - MSM Global Consulting Turns 10!
This year marks a significant milestone for us at MSM Global Consulting as we proudly celebrate our 10th anniversary. Over the past decade, we've grown from a solopreneurship endeavor and a small team with a big vision into a leading force in the field of diversity, equity, inclusion, and organizational change. Our journey has been shaped by the incredible partnerships we've formed, the powerful programs we've developed, and the inspiring communities we've had the privilege to serve. As we reflect on the past ten years, we are filled with gratitude for the unwavering support and trust of our clients, partners, facilitators, contractors, and supporters. Together, we've made strides toward creating more equitable and inclusive environments, and we look forward to continuing this important work with renewed passion and dedication in the years to come. However the winds may shift, we are prepared to weather the storm. 
If you have been inspired, if we have sparked your curiosity, or if you have learned from MSM Global Consulting over the past 10 years, we want to hear from you! Share your story with us at Info@MSMGlobalConsulting.com.
Culture Stew
Culture Stew: Summer Reflection Series 
This summer, we're taking a magnifying glass to four of our Season 5 episodes. We will be looking at how our guests work in, develop and promote different forms of 
liberation
. 
From exploring liberatory consciousness to embracing joy and resilience, we're highlighting powerful discussions on equity, justice, and personal empowerment. Each will offer unique perspectives on navigating societal challenges and fostering meaningful change.
These episodes will be released every other week for the duration of the Summer and leading into Culture Stew, Season 6 in September! 
Episode 1 - Awake to Woke to Work®  with Kay Suarez
 
Episode 2 - Die Standing with Elmer Dixon 
 
Episode 3 -  From Conflict to Connection: A Journey with Todd Culp
 
Episode 4 - Embracing Joy: A Deep Dive into Cultivating Resilience and Authenticity  
    
Stay tuned for the next season coming Fall 2024! 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
Tools for Social Change: How to Develop a Liberatory Consciousness | LEE
 - To dismantle oppression, equity leaders must develop a liberatory consciousness, reclaiming their choices and fostering flexibility for systemic change. Transformational coach Barbara J. Love provides a framework for grounding this essential work, emphasizing awareness, analysis, action, and accountability. These tools help equity leaders cultivate educational equity and combat injustice effectively.
 
How to Imagine a Better Future for Democracy
 
- 
In this TEDx conversation, adrienne maree brown and Baratunde Thurston explore the practice of  “citizening” and imagine a democracy in which everyone feels a deep sense of belonging and true freedom. In it, brown speaks to the notion of “care and repair,” noting that the history of our country has not yet done an adequate job of either. “I think we’re living on an open wound right now,” says brown, “...we were founded on a genocidal colonial act, and we never repaired it. And then we kept building on top of it with more harm.” We need more facilitators, we need more ways to bring diverse voices together to explore and address the complex, nuanced challenges that cannot be solved by one person alone.
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com
 TODAY! 
CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
 
 
"The Breadwinner" 
This animated film tells the story of Parvana, an 11-year-old girl living in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan. When her father is unjustly imprisoned, Parvana disguises herself as a boy to support her family - she defies the gender restrictions imposed on women, demonstrating personal and familial liberation. The film highlights themes of courage, resilience, and the struggle for freedom, portraying the harsh realities of life under oppressive regimes while celebrating the strength of the human spirit. Her story is a powerful example of resilience and the fight for liberation against tyranny. 
 
Anne's Story 
Anne Frank was a Jewish girl who went into hiding during World War II to escape the Nazis. She is best known for her diary, which she kept while hiding with her family in a secret annex in Amsterdam. Her writings provide a poignant and insightful look into the experiences and fears of a young girl during the Holocaust. Anne's diary, published posthumously as "The Diary of a Young Girl," has become one of the world's most powerful memoirs, symbolizing the tragic impact of war and the enduring human spirit. 
From the Anne Frank House YouTube playlist:  “If you don't have the opportunity to visit the Anne Frank House, check out this series. In fourteen short episodes, a virtual Anne Frank tells her story and guides you through the museum. In English with English and Dutch subtitles.”
Watch the series on 
YouTube
, and learn more on their 
website
.

Dear Tamara,
 
Please join our July Community Call for an open discussion around Project 2025. 
 
BRIDGE member companies have asked us to provide the industry with education on Project 2025 as to its contents and the potential implications on employees and business that might result from recommended policy changes.
 
To begin this education effort, we will discuss key sections of the manifesto to get you familiar with an outline of contents and some of the points that directly affect our work. 
 
And, as always, we will provide a safe space to discuss your concerns and thoughts.
 
When: July 25, 12pm ET
Where: Zoom 
Add to Calendar
 
See you soon,
SD
 
Sheryl Daija
Founder & CEO
BRIDGE
 
#wearebridge
#wearestrongertogether
­
Accessibility & Accommodations
This is a one-hour video call but participants are not required to be on video and can dial in by phone, if needed. 
 
The format is facilitated group discussion and CART real-time captioning will be provided. The meeting is not recorded to encourage sharing openly and to preserve confidentiality. 
 
Some key points will be shown via Powerpoint presentation - if you'd like a copy of that in advance, or if you need any other accessibility accommodations for you to participate in this session, please email 
erica@wearebridge.com
 no later than 
July 19th.
 
You can also send your comments and questions in advance to: wearestrongertogether@wearebridge.com
BRIDGE, 1276 Auto Park Way Suite D, PMB 183, Escondido, CA 92029, United States

body:
Why Everyone Needs to Know About Project 2025͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ ͏‌ 
 
­ 
JULY 2024
 
I’m back from an energizing and productive week in Cannes, where I had the privilege to represent BRIDGE at the 
Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity
. I was grateful to find widespread interest in our message of “Inclusion is good for business” and humbled by the outreach from
other attendees to connect and learn more. The experience left me optimistic for the future of BRIDGE’s mission!
 
Now, as I pick back up the rhythm of work and home, my thoughts increasingly turn to one of the biggest threats we as a community and country are facing: Project 2025.
 
If you’re unaware, Project 2025 is a sweeping 900-page conservative transition agenda that, among its many disruptive proposed policy and administrative changes, would dismantle DEI's legal and political foundation. 
The negative impact these proposed changes will have on business growth could be profound. As Prof. Kenji Yoshino said, it’s a “180-day plan to dismantle not just parts of our lives, but our work in this world.” 
 
In keeping with BRIDGE’s mission to build a more inclusive workplace and marketplace, we have convened a board level steering committee to provide clear and concise education to the industry on the direct implications Project 2025 will have on business and employees, especially the most vulnerable and already underrepresented. 
 
In the coming weeks, we'll share details about the specific deliverables so please stay tuned. For starters, we will focus on Project 2025 in our next community call - see below for more information.
 
More to come,
SD
#wearestrongertogether
#weareBRIDGE
­
Find Use Cases for Inclusion
If you missed last month’s Use Cases for Inclusion presentation by Omar Rodríguez-Vilá, PhD, Professor of Marketing Practice at Emory University’s Goizueta Business School, you can now watch it on-demand.
Watch Now
 
What you’ll learn:
 
-Inclusion as a Brand Benefit:
 Understand the correlation between consumers’ perception of inclusion and their purchase intent
 
-Inclusion to Drive Engagement:
 Review how different messaging conditions (inclusion, diversity, exclusion) affected brand engagement
 
-Inclusion to Improve Purchase Intent:
 Measure inclusion impact across various facets of a business, from in-store experiences to product offerings and communication strategies in driving purchase intent
­
Sign Up Today!
 
The BRIDGE STRONGER TOGETHER Community Call is a vibrant monthly gathering of diversity, marketing and business leaders committed to driving systemic change within our organizations and the industry at large.
 
This month’s focus is on Project 2025. (read more above)
 
As Project 2025 is a direct attack on the practice of DEI, BRIDGE member companies have asked us to provide the industry with education as to its contents and the potential implications these policy changes will have on employees and business.
 
To start with this education effort, the July Community Call will be an open discussion and primer to get you familiar with an outline of contents and some of the key points that directly affect our work.
 
Join us for Stronger Together Community Calls! Save the Dates:
 
September 27, 2024, 12pm ET
October 31, 2024, 12pm ET
November 21, 2024 12pm ET
Add July Call To Calendar
 
­
Building Capabilities for Inclusive Brands
Inclusive Marketing has been identified as a critical gap in the building of inclusive brands. It has long been a challenge for the industry falling under the rubric of “Multicultural Marketing”, a clear misnomer. However, as much dialog as there has been, the ecosystem still does not function as efficiently or effectively as it should.  
The Inclusive Marketing Development Committee, a 
powerful cross-ecosystem consortium of over 40 brands, agencies, and technology companies group is at the forefront of identifying and implementing next practices for inclusive marketing
, directly contributing to the industry-wide change BRIDGE envisions.
To learn more or find out how to get involved, email 
wearestrongertogether@wearebridge.com
­
"BRIDGE is everywhere! I was humbled by the warm reception BRIDGE received at Cannes  - this surprise from Media.Monks warmed my heart!" 
­
BRIDGE Webinar Series: Understanding Inclusion: Find Use Cases, Not Business Cases
 
Most Americans approve of DEI, according to Post-Ipsos poll
Roughly 6 in 10 Americans said DEI programs are “a good thing” — and support was even higher for specific programs such as internships for underrepresented groups.
 
Sephora says people of color now make up half its leadership because it ‘disrupted’ the recruitment process
 
 
­ 
 
­ 
 
 
BRIDGE
1276 Auto Park Way Suite D, PMB 183, Escondido, 92029

subject: Pride Month: Rainbow logo? It's a start...
body:
We've all heard phrases like “walk the walk”, “actions speak louder than words”, but how many companies live by this?
 
 
Dear colleagues,
We've all heard phrases like “walk the walk”, “put your money where your mouth is”, “actions speak louder than words”, but how many companies live by this?
It’s Pride Month! A month to memorialise, celebrate, and demand justice. It’s not hard to find out how the LGBTQIA+ community has been persecuted and oppressed, so the focus of this article is on the “what can we do?”. Lots of companies will change their logo to reflect a rainbow, and they may change packaging for products, or even have a fabulous keynote speaker do a talk.
But is this enough?
Based on our 
maturity model
, the above would fit firmly in diversity 2.0. This is largely about marketing, about appearing as a diverse organisation, or capitalising on movements in order to increase visibility. Of course, actions in solidarity like the above have a place in allyship and diversity and inclusion work, but cannot be the be all and end all.
At 
Included
, we dare organisations to aim for inclusion 4.0; having diversity and inclusion at the very centre of everything they do. This means not just thinking about sending a solidarity message to a community (which we did in our last newsletter!), but using the very service, product, and infrastructure of the company to build and uphold inclusion.
So how can we move from messages of solidarity, to action?
This depends on the community that you’re wishing to serve or include, so let’s take pride month and the LGBTQIA+ community as an example.
A message of solidarity in the form of a change logo, a special announcement from the CEO, or a guest speaker is a great starting point. Think about how you can internalise these messages: have you got ERGs for this community? Have you got representation of the community at senior levels? Do your senior leaders understand, appreciate, and embrace the community?
Here’s a breakdown, based on our pillars, of a generalised approach to including the LGBTQIA+ community. 
Strategy
: Is this community explicitly named in your strategy so they may be consciously included (as opposed to unconsciously excluded)?
 
Data
: Do you have an understanding of the representation of LGBTQIA+ people in your organisation, and how included or excluded they feel?
 
Governance
: Is there a employee resource group for members of the LGBTQIA+ community and allies to create a safe space, and channel of communication to senior leaders? Are members compensated for their time?
 
Leadership
: Are your leaders (formal leaders, or cultural leaders) informed on the history, context, and current experiences of people in the LGBTQIA+ community, and they actively advocating for them? Are they incentivised to do so?
 
Systems
: Do your policies explicitly acknowledge and support your LGBTQIA+ colleagues? For example, is your parental leave truly inclusive? This means including global cover for adoption, fostering, surrogacy, IVF, IUI, and miscarriage, and making no assumptions about the gender, sex, or sexuality of parents, pregnant or birthing people, or carers. It also means not forcing disclosure of sex, gender, sexuality, pregnancy or parental status.
Having a rainbow logo for the month is a great way to publicly show your appreciation and support for a community, but it actually does very little to make a tangible difference to the community both inside your company, and in the wider world. That being said, if you’re anxious or nervous about taking bigger leaps, don’t let that stop you. Get in touch with us and we can help.
Bonus tips: 
Pay your speakers, community leaders, and LGBTQIA+ colleagues fairly.
 
Remember identities intersect – there are Black, disabled, working class, neurodivergent, religious LGBTQIA+ people of all shapes, sizes, and ages. Represent and acknowledge all LGBTQIA+ folks.
 
Educate yourself. If you are not part of the LGBTQIA+ community and want to learn more, don’t rely on your peers to educate you on the community, or justify their existence. There is a wealth of resources out there, and many helpful groups for learning and building empathy.
 
People may be ‘out’ in some situations, but not others. For example, they may use different pronouns around family, or refer to their partner differently in the workplace. Follow their lead and never disclose information on someone else’s behalf without their permission.
 
Remember that being in close proximity to somebody in the LGBTQIA+ community does not give you a right to speak on their behalf, or take ownership over their experiences. Having a gay family member does not give you the insight or experience of being gay yourself. Be conscious of the distinction.
If we are working with you this month, feel free to ask us directly about these topics, and if you have a story to share please get in touch via email at 
info@included.com
. By valuing and supporting individuals, your organisation can better your people’s experiences at work and unlock the full potential of your workforce.
  
 
EDI: Where are we now?
  
Included CEO Michelle Sequeira and chair Stephen Frost discuss the current state of play when it comes to equity, diversity and inclusion.
 Learn more about out how you and your firm can help to support a culture of inclusion and respect.
 
Read now
 
Certificate in Diversity and Inclusion In The Workplace
  
This certification course aims to provide a thorough understanding of the main components of diversity, equity, equality, inclusion and belonging. Devised and delivered by two leading D&I organisations in the UK & Ireland, 
Included
 and Legal Island.
This course is suited for business leaders, HR professionals and passionate DEI advocates who are dedicated to building inclusive cultures within their organisations. It will also suit organisations with a newly created D&I post wanting to access immediately relevant knowledge, contacts and networks.

here

Please 
get in touch

body:
Dear Tamara,
 
I hope you can join us for this month’s Community Call where we’ll dig deeper into the latest research insights from 
"
Understanding Inclusion: Find Use Cases, Not Business Cases
, a study led by Dr. Omar Rodríguez-Vilá on 
inclusion as a brand benefit and its impact on engagement and purchase intent
.
 
If you missed the webinar presentation,  you can watch it 
here
.  We’ll also feature some key takeaways and look forward to your questions and comments.

Where: Zoom 
Add to Calendar
 
See you soon,
SD
 
Sheryl Daija
Founder & CEO
BRIDGE
 
#wearebridge
#wearestrongertogether

Accessibility & Accommodations
This is a one-hour video call but participants are not required to be on video and can dial in by phone, if needed. 
 
The format is facilitated group discussion and CART real-time captioning will be provided. The meeting is not recorded to encourage sharing openly and to preserve confidentiality. 
 
Some key highlights from the research presentation will be shown - if you'd like a copy of that in advance, or if you need any other accessibility accommodations for you to participate in this session, please email

subject: The Importance of Inclusive Communication
body:
The Importance of Inclusive Communication
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Hi Tamara,
Our latest article, 
"The Importance of Inclusive Communication,"
 explores the critical role that effective communication plays in fostering respect, collaboration, and innovation in the modern workplace.
 
Key Highlights:
The Growing Need for Effective Communication:
 With a 50% increase in collaborative activities over the past two decades, effective communication has become more essential than ever.
Impact on Team Dynamics:
 Discover how respectful and inclusive communication can enhance job satisfaction, productivity, and overall team performance.
Challenges of Incivility:
 Learn about the far-reaching consequences of rude and disrespectful communication, including its impact on individual health and wellbeing.
AI's Role in Enhancing Communication:
 Understand how advanced AI tools can promote positive language and help create more inclusive workplaces by acting as continuous communication coaches.

We’re introducing new terms on the use of Miro AI features
On July 17, 2024, we’re introducing a new 
AI Features Addendum
 that will supplement the agreement you have with Miro. We’re also updating the 
Miro Privacy Policy 
. These changes make it easier for you to understand what to expect from Miro as you use our AI features, such as Miro Assist.
You can review the new terms 
here
. At a glance, these updates explain:
•
How Miro uses inputs you provide and output generated by Miro AI features.
•
Ownership of output generated by Miro’s AI features.
•
Limitations associated with the quickly-evolving technologies that underpin Miro AI features.
You don't have to do anything to accept these changes. By continuing to use Miro after July 17th you are agreeing to the new terms. If you have questions check the FAQ below.
AI Features Addendum FAQ
We don’t train generative AI with your board content.
 Miro relies on commercially available models (such as developed by OpenAI) as well as open-source models that are trained with licensed data and public domain content where copyright has expired. Miro may use usage data and other meta data to improve your product experience and develop features like diagramming and sticky clustering.
You can choose not to participate in our AI feature improvement efforts.
 We currently don’t use your input into and output from Miro AI features to improve our product. If we intend to change our training approach, we will inform you upfront.
You own your board content.
 No license granted to Miro to operate its services will supersede your ownership rights.
Thank you for using Miro! 
The Miro Team
