subject: Designing the Future for Diversity, Equity & Inclusion
body:
How do we advance the field of DEI?
 
 
 
How do we advance the field of DEI?
 
The question of how to evolve the work of diversity, equity and inclusion is a longstanding one. For decades, practitioners have debated over how to standardize this work and whether it is even feasible to do so. Since 2020, the demand for DEI expertise has grown. Even in the face of conservative backlash to DEI efforts (which most longtime DEI professionals anticipated) there is an ever-increasing acknowledgment that DEI is a strategic imperative for any organization. Not only do diverse and inclusive teams perform better and the competencies that leaders who embrace DEI principles lead to better results, but also the next generation of the workforce demands it. A recent Monster.com study found that 
83% of Gen Z job seekers
 said that a potential employer’s commitment to DEI would be an important part of their decision to seek employment. 
Although there are some certification programs for DEI practitioners, simply doing a one-time training or taking an online course will not suffice. DEI work requires a multitude of skills that cannot be taught all at once in a classroom setting. 
I don’t have a definitive answer to the question I posed above. I’m not sure if a certifying body or centralized approach to DEI work is feasible or functional. However, here are a few strategies we as a field should consider:
Build a base of knowledge AND explore new methods. Decades of research and practical application have been done and identified maturity models, best practices, and benchmarks for DEI. 
The Global Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Benchmarks (GDEIB)
 is a well-researched strategic framework created in collaboration with over 100 global DEI practitioners. However, the work of DEI is susceptible to evolving workplace and societal trends, and we need to continue to adapt our approach to what works for organizations today.
 
Mentor the next generation AND learn from them.  On a regular basis with my clients, I see professionals under 40 dismissed by their elders, and the DEI profession is no different. We need to be vigilant about providing opportunities for Millennial and Gen Z DEI professionals to grow their skills and advance in their careers. Likewise, the new generation of professionals brings innovative (and sometimes better) approaches to the work. An organization doing excellent work in preparing the next generation of DEI leaders is 
IDEAS Generation
, which has established a community of practitioners and provides a Fellowship program that offers real life consulting opportunities, educational resources, and opportunities for professional development.
 
Strive to expand the coalition AND care for the “choir.” It is no secret that we are in the midst of deep societal polarization where even terms like “inclusion” and “belonging” are deemed by some as politically divisive. The only way to fight this misrepresentation of our work is by widening the pool of individuals who see themselves as a core part of DEI work. The more we stay in our proverbial echo chambers, the more we contribute to “us/them” thinking. This means that many of us need to prepare to do the emotional labor of engaging with people who may be apathetic or resistant to exploring and embracing DEI. We also need to do a better job of true self-care to balance the toll this emotional labor takes on us.
This October, MSM Global and our partners at True Change Associates are hosting the second annual 
Ember program at the University of Colorado Denver
. The three-day event will convene a powerful community of DEI change agents to engage in robust learning around how to develop and sustain momentum in their DEI work. We hope you can join us for this enriching experience and to join a community of leaders from across industries working to and explore strategic approaches to transform their organizations. Check out MSM Global Updates below for more information on how to register!
 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
Join Us for an Informational Session on EMBER: Igniting and Sustaining a Community of Equity Practitioners
Did you know that the embers of a fire burn hotter than the flames? Embers ignite the flames and sustain the heat even when the fire begins to fade. When it comes to leading efforts for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI), we need to 
be
 the embers, helping to ignite and sustain the fire for long-term change. On July 9th, we invite you to an informational session about EMBER, a transformative program designed to build a vibrant, purpose-driven community of aspiring and experienced DEI practitioners. Learn how EMBER goes beyond standard training by fostering deep self-reflection, peer coaching, and research-based DEI practices. Join us to discover how you can become part of a cohort of change agents dedicated to sustainable institutional transformation. Don't miss this opportunity to be a part of something bigger – ignite and sustain the fire for DEI change. Learn more about the informational session 
here
!
Register Today! 
- Discounted Registration Ends June 30th! 
 
EMBER: Igniting a DEI Collective
 - Culture Stew Blog by Roger Moreano
In December 2023, DEI professionals gathered for Ember, a three-day program by MSM Global Consulting and True Change Associates, designed to provide a sanctuary amidst ongoing political and cultural backlash. In this new blog from Roger Moreano, he reflects on his participation in Ember. Ember emerged as a sanctuary for DEI professionals amidst relentless culture wars and political backlash. Roger found that Ember reignited a path forward, emphasizing the importance of community, strategy, and self-care.
The program underscores the importance of community, strategy, and self-care in sustaining DEI efforts. Join us for the next Ember program in Colorado this October 2024 to experience this transformative journey. Learn more on the Culture Stew blog! 
Culture Stew
Embracing Joy: A Deep Dive into Cultivating Resilience and Authenticity
 Join us for a profound exploration of joy, resilience, and authenticity in the latest episode of Culture Stew!  Host Maria Morukian engages in a heartfelt conversation with Danne L. Johnson, Kai Stowers, and Wendy Moomaw.
In this poignant episode, Danne, Kai and Wendy help us explore the  intersection of joy and self-awareness, and provide techniques for overcoming societal pressures that erode resilience.
The Emotional Journey of DEI: Navigating Resistance and Advocacy
 
We’ve come to the end of another incredible season of Culture Stew. Thank you to all our amazing guests who brought insights, laughter, and profound learning to our bimonthly conversations..
In this season finale, hosts Maria Morukian and Roger Moreano dive deep into the emotional journey of DEI work, addressing both the heartfelt challenges and the practical hurdles of navigating resistance and advocacy. They explore the emotional toll DEI work can take, emphasizing the importance of recognizing and validating this labor.
    
Stay tuned for the next season coming Fall 2024! 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
The Vital Role Of Coaching In Diversity, Equity And Inclusion
 - Discover how coaching can significantly enhance diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts within organizations. This insightful article from Forbes highlights the essential role of coaching in fostering inclusive environments and building cultures of belonging. Learn about the strategies and benefits of integrating coaching into DEI initiatives to support meaningful and sustainable change.
 
A Better Approach to Mentorship
 - 
Explore innovative strategies for reshaping the mentoring landscape to foster inclusivity and build cultures of belonging. This Harvard Business Review article delves into how effective mentorship can drive diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts within organizations. Discover the benefits of adopting a more inclusive approach to mentorship and how it can support professional growth and organizational success.
Real Mentors
 - 
Real Mentors Network is the world’s first inclusive mentoring platform that offers professionals the business power of LinkedIn with the matching features like famous dating websites! It harnesses the power of technology to take the guesswork out of mentoring, matching mentors and mentees from across industries and the globe.
Real Mentors Network is a black women-owned start-up, led by its founder Tamara Thorpe, who has leveraged nearly two decades of leadership and organizational development consulting experience to create an online platform that makes access to mentors more equitable.
The platform provides a place and space to become a mentor or to find a mentor to foster genuine, impactful, and inclusive mentoring relationships between individuals at any point in their careers to support their professional growth, development and advancement.
As an expert in building workplace confidence, Tamara Thorpe has listened to and experienced the disconnect between generations and their professional growth. In helping organizations develop and advance their own talent, Tamara has realized that one of the most important factors was to have mentors that provide safe spaces for learning and allow the rising generations to ask the necessary questions, learn, grow and transition into new roles or careers. - To find or become a mentor go to 
realmentors.net
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com

CONTENT FOR YOUR DOWN TIME
Here are some recommended articles and books for your down time.
 
 
 
30 Days of Pride: LGBTQ+ Movies to Celebrate Pride Month
In honor of Pride Month, check out this curated list of LGBTQ+ movies compiled by the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus. The article, "30 Days of Pride: LGBTQ+ Movies to Celebrate Pride Month," offers a diverse selection of films that highlight and celebrate LGBTQ+ stories, voices, and experiences. Dive into these powerful narratives to gain deeper insights and appreciation for the LGBTQ+ community.
 
The 2024 Goodreads Pride Reading List 
Celebrate Pride Month and beyond with this comprehensive reading list from Goodreads. This article features a diverse array of books that showcase LGBTQ+ voices and stories. Whether you're looking for fiction, non-fiction, or poetry, this list has something for everyone.
Here are some highlights from the list: 
A Minor Chorus by: Billy-Ray Belcourt - Hijab Butch Blues by: Lamya H. 
Body Grammar by: Jules Ohman
Pageboy by: Elliot Page - Greta & Valdin by: Rebecca K. Reilly

Dear Tamara,
 
During our recent 
BRIDGE Webinar, "Understanding Inclusion: Find Use Cases, Not Business Cases
," Dr. Omar Rodriguez-Vila of Emory University presented insights from proprietary research on inclusion as a brand benefit and its impact on engagement and purchase intent.
 
In our next community call, please join us for an interactive discussion as we dig deeper into how you can apply this research internally and how you think of inclusion as a new brand metric for growth.
 
When: June 27, 12pm ET
Where: Zoom 
Add to Calendar
 
See you soon,
SD
 
Sheryl Daija
Founder & CEO
BRIDGE
 
#wearebridge
#wearestrongertogether
­
Accessibility & Accommodations
This is a one-hour video call but participants are not required to be on video and can dial in by phone, if needed. 
 
The format is facilitated group discussion and CART real-time captioning will be provided. The meeting is not recorded to encourage sharing openly and to preserve confidentiality. 
 
Some key highlights from the research presentation will be shown - if you'd like a copy of that in advance, or if you need any other accessibility accommodations for you to participate in this session, please email 
erica@wearebridge.com
 no later than 
June 20th.
 
You can also send your comments and questions in advance to: wearestrongertogether@wearebridge.com

subject: 🌈 Valuing LGBTQI+ People in Organisations: A Path to Innovation and Inclusivity
body:
Hi Tamara,
As we celebrate 
Pride Month
, we are excited to share our latest article that delves into the critical importance of recognising and valuing LGBTQI+ individuals within organisations. This insightful piece explores the undeniable benefits of fostering an inclusive workplace, backed by robust research and real-world examples.
Key Highlights:
Innovation Through Diversity
: Discover how celebrating LGBTQI+ employees can drive creativity and unique solutions within your team.
Employee Satisfaction and Retention
: Learn how inclusive environments boost morale, loyalty, and overall job satisfaction.
Organisational Impact
: Understand the significant costs of exclusion and the rise in negative rhetoric against LGBTQI+ communities.
Actionable Steps for Allies
: Gain practical strategies for supporting LGBTQI+ colleagues and creating a welcoming workplace.
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Symmetra Pty Ltd, Quay Quarter Towers, Level 2, 50 Bridge Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 Australia, hello@symmetraglobal.com

subject: Unlock the Power of DE&I in Your Organization – Join Our Exclusive Webinar
body:
Are you ready to take your organization to new heights by championing Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion? Join us for an exclusive webinar that delves into the critical role senior leaders play in fostering a culture of inclusion and belonging. 
 
Date:
 Thursday, June 27, 2024
Time:
 4 pm GMT | 8 am PST | 10 am CST | 11 am EST
 
Hi Tamara, 
 
Are you ready to take your organization to new heights by championing diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I)? Join us for an exclusive webinar that delves into the critical role senior leaders play in fostering a culture of inclusion and belonging.
 
Why Attend '
You Can't Spell 'Direction' Without DE&I'?
 
When senior leaders aren’t fully committed to DE&I, organizations face significant challenges: stunted growth, diminished employee engagement and morale, and turnover like a revolving door. Yet, with top-down commitment, the benefits are maximized: increased employee engagement and productivity, enhanced workplace wellbeing, and the ability to attract and retain top talent.
 
Key Topics We’ll Cover:
The Right Direction for Your Organization:
 How getting DE&I right actually helps your organization head in the right direction.
Leadership Buy-In:
 The impact of DE&I leadership buy-in on employee wellbeing, engagement, and retention.
Risks of Inauthentic Commitment:
 The risks to the organization and individuals when there is inauthentic leadership commitment to DE&I.
Real Reasons for Turnover:
 The real reasons why people leave jobs (heads-up, it’s not just the money).
Role of Leaders:
 The role that leaders at all levels in the organization have to play in building a culture of inclusion and belonging.
Don't miss out, sign up today!
 
Sign Up Today!
We look forward to seeing you at the webinar and working together to make a positive, lasting impact in your organization.
 
Join the conversation live, and let’s work together towards making the workplace work for everyone.
 
Can’t make it? Don’t worry – sign up and we’ll make sure to send you a recording of the webinar after.
See what else is planned
 
No Overnight Successes: Why You Need to Commit to DEI
Why businesses must be prepared for the long haul in their DE&I initiatives.
Understanding the nature and pace of cultural change.
Maintaining momentum and morale toward long-term DE&I goals.
24th July 2024 
Register for Webinar
 
 
 
 
 
The full name of our company is Talking Talent Ltd. We are registered in England & Wales under registration number 05617899. Our registered address is Talking Talent Ltd, 60 Chiswell Street, Milton Gate, London, London EC1Y 4AG, United Kingdom

Hi Tamara,
This is Jeff from 
Calendly
 with some tips and product updates to make meetings easier and more productive. By the way, you can find all our past newsletters from the last year on our new 
release notes page
!
Integrations of the Month: Slack and Microsoft Teams
As a user of Calendly, I've always felt like our 
long list of integrations
 has made us stand out. And it's much easier to build good integrations when the companies themselves support us in doing so! 
We're pals with both Slack and Microsoft who have helped us integrate well with their messaging apps. Our updated 
Slack
 and 
Microsoft Teams
 chat apps send you real-time notifications to keep you updated on your Calendly meetings and activity. Meaning, Slack and Teams will alert you when you book a new meeting, someone cancels, and more. 
Slack:
Try Slack Integration
 
Microsoft Teams:
Try Teams Integration
 
Cleaning Up Meetings
 
We have amazing customers around the world; however, for us at Calendly, summer is around the corner. And as a meeting-obsessed company, our “spring cleaning” looked a little different. Instead of dusting off the baseboards, we are: 
- 
Ensuring, if we have a meeting, it has a purpose
. Otherwise, let's recycle it. Are we just meeting to meet, or does the meeting have a specific topic: project retrospective, status meeting, or problem-solving (my favorite). 
- 
Tidying up our meetings
 by sending agendas, writing pre-meeting documents about the topic at hand, offering digital whiteboards to make meetings more engaging, and more. 
Since Calendly is a remote-first company, one of my favorite meeting hygiene tips is: 
Set people up for success to join your meeting, no matter where they are
. 
That means making sure you set up your 
meeting location
—video call, phone, in-person—in your event types in advance. I like to add what kind of meeting it is (e.g., 30-Minute Video Call) to my event type name (to remind the attendee—and me!). 
And you can even offer the flexibility of multiple options, letting your invitee pick their tool of choice. 
And if you’re the one in need of some location flexibility, 
Calendly’s mobile app
 can help.
Use our mobile app to view and join meetings on the go, quickly grab your scheduling link, or reschedule in a pinch. You can also opt into notifications for when someone schedules, shifts, or cancels a call with you. 
Got your own meeting hygiene tips? Share on social using the #BetterMeetings hashtag so we can follow along and continue the conversation. 
Download for iOS or Android
 
Other Resources
Webinar: 
Getting Started With Calendly
 
Webinar: 
Using Calendly as a Team
 
Blog Post: 
8 Most Common Types of Meetings
 
Blog Post: 
How to Run a Better, Smarter Meeting
 
Article: 
TechCrunch on the Calendly Browser Extension
 
Article: 
CustomerThink byline
 by Head of User Experience, Jess Clark 
Thanks for reading,
Jeff Hardison
Head of Product Marketing @ Calendly
More than a scheduling link.

subject: The Evolution of Workplace Culture: the role of AI
body:
The Evolution of Workplace Culture: the role of AI
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Hi Tamara,
Our latest article discusses the future of workplace culture and the transformative role of AI.  As global expectations and legislative requirements evolve, it's crucial for organisations to stay ahead in creating safe and inclusive environments.
In this article, we delve into the significance of the new positive duty legislation in UK and Australia and explore how AI solutions can help organisations meet these standards. From enhancing reporting mechanisms to providing real-time feedback for respectful communication, AI offers powerful tools to foster a respectful workplace culture.
 
Key Highlights:
The growing global expectations regarding respect at work.
The complexity of organisational cultural issues.
Common challenges organisations face in creating respectful workplaces.
How AI can provide solutions for reporting, risk mitigation, policy compliance, and real-time feedback.
READ THE FULL ARTICLE

subject: Training for HRBPs - July
body:
Hi Tamara,
How are you? 
Donna would like to schedule an HRBP training that you would facilitate on the below subject in July.
Provide HR community with DEI training annually to address skill gaps and strengthen HRBP ownership of DEI objectives.
 
Would it be possible to identify a date the week of July 8th and 15th?  Ideally not a Monday or Friday.   Let's identify a 2 hour window - and can be all virtual. 
We have trained on Leading with Inclusion and that could be a great base for this training - but will get more details on what skill gap we need to focus on.  
If we could start on the dates so we can report back that we are moving forward with this - that would be amazing!!! 
Let me know! 
Thank you,
Gaëlle

subject: Mental Health Awareness Week 2024
body:
You don't often get email from info@included.com. 
Learn why this is important
Taking the time to focus on our mental well-being has never been more essential.
 
 
Dear colleagues,
Taking the time to focus on our mental well-being has never been more essential.
We believe that sharing experiences and strategies can make a significant difference in how we manage stress, anxiety, and overall mental health. This week we’ve asked members of our team to share some personal insights and effective tips that have enhanced their mental well-being.
Whether you're looking for new ways to unwind after a busy day, seeking strategies to manage workplace stress, or simply need a reminder that you're not alone in your journey, hopefully our team's experiences can help.
Vikki
 finds being in nature can help to balance busy days: 
“I love country walks and have recognised how refreshing and grounding I find being outdoors in nature.  To maintain balance and maintain my own mental health I make an effort to schedule time to step away from the desk to walk the dog during lunch and get some fresh air.
If I’m finding work and life particularly busy I make sure I pause for a longer walk over the weekend to completely reset. I find it amazing how a long country walk gives me the mental time and space to think things through, process and regroup.”
Meditation and time management are particularly effective for 
Michelle
: 
“Regular doses of focusing on my breath and clearing my mind has led to me feeling more resilient. This is alongside being more active with a balance of high intensity classes in there too.
I also have a 5/35 past rule - I try to start each meeting at 5 past (or 35 past) instead of trying to end with 5 mins to spare. I found the latter is often eaten up, but by starting later I have a guaranteed breather for either the quick break or to get an urgent action ticked off. This leaves me both more refreshed and having fewer actions later on in the evening too.”
Lydia
 has benefited from counselling and acknowledging that we can only control so much in our lives: 
“For me, talking therapy has been really useful in interrupting the day-to-day and offering time for reflection. Not all talking therapy has felt right for me, but I've recently found a neurodivergent affirming counsellor who is fabulous. She's helping me understand not only my feelings and experiences, but how they connect to my neurotype. So often we don't allow ourselves the time to be the 'centre of attention', or the person being helped - but we deserve this support too.
If I'm feeling buried under too many worries/stresses, I find it useful to list everything, then identify which I have any control over. Those I don't, I try to mindfully acknowledge that, and those I do, I identify exactly how I can make the change I need.
Small changes, big shifts; they all add up.
 
Anthony
 has discovered benefits in all areas of life from regular exercise: 
"Before I started going to the gym regularly, I found myself in a relentless cycle of stress and anxiety. It's amazing how working out (even just two or three times per week) can alter your outlook and make such a difference in your life.
I noticed physical benefits almost immediately - boosted energy levels, more focus/productivity and generally feeling healthier and more resilient.
But more importantly, my gym sessions have become a dedicated time to disconnect from the pressures of the outside world. Regular workouts have positively affected my mental energy and balance, and I find myself able to be more present in everything I do. Exercise not only transforms your body, but your mindset too."
Hopefully these insights have sparked new ideas and remember, taking care of your mental health is a vital component of overall well-being, and small, consistent steps can lead to significant positive changes.
You can find more resources and discussions on enhancing your mental health, managing stress, and achieving a healthier work-life balance in your business by exploring 
this article
.
You can also read about some simple steps to reduce stress in your workplace 
here
.
Please continue to take care of yourself, support others and build a community where open conversations about mental health are encouraged.
Feel free to share any stories or tips of your own, and please don't hesitate to reach out to us anytime to have a conversation with one of our 
team
 to discuss our making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive. 
  
Top DEI Challenges in 2024 and How to Solve Them
  
In partnership with Legal Island, this webinar, delivered by CEO 
Michelle Sequeira
, is suited for business leaders, HR professionals and passionate DEI advocates who are dedicated to building inclusive cultures within their organisations.
Michelle brings a wealth of experience and a fresh perspective on how inclusivity can drive organisational success. Her passion for actionable solutions makes her a dynamic leader in the DEI space – you won’t want to miss this one!
Register for free here
 
Stress and work-life balance: what companies can do to support their people
  
At 
Included
 we advocate for an awareness and reduction of stress at all times – but today we are running with the theme and wanted to explore one area of our working lives that can impact our experience of stress: a healthy work-life balance.
We look at the experience of one demographic in the workplace and ask, what can companies do to make work-life balance work?
Read the article
 
Find out more about 
Included
’s approach to diversity 
here
 and take a look at our 
Impact Report
. 
Please 
get in touch
 with us anytime to have a conversation about making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive.  We look forward to hearing from you. 
From all of us at

Dear Tamara,
 
What an amazing few days when DEI, Marketing & Business leaders came together for our 2nd annual retreat at 
BRIDGE24
! We can’t wait to share some of the key learnings and actionable and takeaways with you all!
 
When: May 30, 12pm ET
Where: Zoom 
Add to Calendar
 
Learn what the next generation thinks about The Future of Work, including the impact of AI and hybrid models
Understand the why, what and how of Inclusive Media and Marketing, and the business imperative for brands to achieve their full growth potential
Hear what experts had to say about the impact of the SCOTUS Affirmative Action decision and the dissolution of the US Office of Diversity and Inclusion on Business
 
#wearebridge
#wearestrongertogether
 
See you soon,
 
Sheryl Daija
Founder & CEO
BRIDGE

subject: Three helpful resources if you are experiencing online harassment!
body:
You have the right to feel safe online! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 | 
www.righttobe.org 
Dear friend, 
According to a survey by the Pew Research Center, 
41% of Americans have reported being harassed online in their lifetime.  
If you or someone you know is experiencing online harassment, we want to remind you that you're valued and you have the right to feel safe and respected online. Today, 
we want to share three valuable resources that might provide you with support and guidance. 
 
Practicing digital security and enhancing your social media accounts is important to protect your data and ensure that harassment doesn’t escalate into further harm, such as taking over your accounts or personal information. 
This guide walks you through some immediate steps
 to feel safer and strengthen your privacy
 online.
 
Right To Be's 
Hate and Hope Tracker 
is a secure tool where you can share your story of harassment and get help. 
If you are experiencing online harassment, you can receive or provide help
 in the form of supportive messages, or by helping report or document abuse on social media. 
Join our community no
w!
 
Ps. You may not have a story to share, or you may not feel comfortable sharing it now, but 
on our
 Hate and Hope Tracker
, you can also share stories of hate and harassment that you see in the news or on social media. 
Those 
stories help us raise awareness and show the realities and impacts of harassment
. 
As we move through the 2024 US Election, we also want to shine a light on election-related hate. 
Please feel free to share a media story on our platform now
!
Online harassment has profound negative impacts and can lead to depression and anxiety. Being harassed online is not your fault and there is no perfect response. 
This guide provides strategies
 t
o help you take care of yourself 
and develop resilience while experiencing online abuse. 
Please know that you are not alone. We hope these resources can help you navigate through these challenges.
In solidarity, 
Right To Be

Subject:

Hi Tamara,
 
Attached are your last three paystubs. Your last one should’ve been received on Friday, March 15
th
.
At our meeting last week, you decided to go with a monthly payment while working as an external contractor at $6500/month. 
That would mean you would receive your monthly payment for the month of March on May 1
st

We could change it to bi-weekly, which means your first check as an external contractor would get paid out mid-April for $3,250.
 
Let me know which one you would like to go with, and I’ll have the PA drawn up to reflect that.

subject: Exciting Changes Coming Soon! Join Us This Fall
body:
Continue reading to learn about our upcoming changes. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE
 
 
Hi Tamara!
As someone who has shown interest in our content but hasn't yet subscribed to our newsletter, I wanted to reach out and share some important updates with you. 
Firstly, I want to express my gratitude for your interest in our work. Your support means a great deal to us, and we're always striving to provide valuable insights and resources to our community. 
I'm writing to inform you that we'll be taking a brief hiatus from our regular newsletter schedule this summer. This decision is due to some previously scheduled travels and a significant family event - my daughter's wedding in June. It's a special time for us, and we're taking this opportunity to recharge and prepare for an exciting return in the fall. 
During this hiatus, we'll be busy rebranding and strategizing for the future. Our goal is to come back stronger than ever, with more relevant and impactful content focused on creating better workplaces. We'll be exploring new topics, sharing fresh perspectives, and providing actionable tips and strategies to empower professionals like yourself. 
While we won't be sending out regular newsletters over the summer, we may occasionally revisit some of our most popular articles. It's a chance to reflect on valuable insights and reinforce key learnings that continue to resonate with our audience. 
As we gear up for our return in the fall, I wanted to extend an invitation to you to join our newsletter community. By subscribing, you'll gain access to exclusive content, insightful articles, and practical resources designed to help you create a better workplace. 
Signing up is easy - simply click the link below:
 
  
👉 👉 👉 
 
CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE
.
 
 
Rest assured, we'll only send you valuable content that we believe will benefit you on your professional journey. 
Thank you once again for your interest in our work. We're excited about the changes ahead and look forward to welcoming you to our newsletter community this fall.
Wishing you a wonderful summer,
Inclusively yours, 
 
Luiza 
____________________________________________ 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.

subject: Elevate Your Leadership with Our Framework on Inclusive Leadership! 🚀
body:
View in browser
 
 
 
Inclusive Leadership: Time to get Specific 
Get FREE Practical Framework Now
 
Hi Tamara,
The 
Inclusive Leadership Framework
 is a comprehensive tool designed to equip leaders like you with 
specific behaviours
 needed to foster inclusivity within your teams and organisations. Through a series of four insightful articles, we'll delve into key aspects of inclusive leadership, offering practical tips and actionable insights to empower you on your journey towards building a high perfoming, inclusive team and workplace. 
 
First Article: 
The Foundation of Inclusive Leadership: Self-Awareness and Learning Mindset
 delve to the core of the Inclusion Competency model - yourself. In this article, we explore the essential competencies of Awareness and Learning Mindset, guiding you on a journey of self-insight and growth. 
Discover the power of self-awareness in understanding how your inner world influences your interactions and decisions.
Learn to recognise unconscious biases, embrace diverse perspectives, and foster an inclusive environment where everyone feels valued and respected.
Explore the importance of cultivating a learning mindset, embracing curiosity, humility, and openness to new ideas.
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Symmetra Pty Ltd, Quay Quarter Towers, Level 2, 50 Bridge Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 Australia, hello@symmetraglobal.com

subject: May 2024 4-Up Friday
body:
You don't often get email from michellehancock@centerformentoring.com. 
Learn why this is important
May 2024 4-Up Friday
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
In May, our emphasis shifts towards
 the significance of social connection in mentoring
, fostering discussions and insights to enhance our community bonds. We're excited to welcome 
Dr. Janice Molloy
 from the University of Michigan for our 
Thought Leader Conversation
 on 
May 14th
, setting the stage for an enlightening conversation on this vital topic. We hope to 
see you there
. 
Mentor On!
The Team at 
Center for Mentoring Excellence
 
FOUR UP FRIDAY
 
The Surprising Benefits of Social Connections 
Loneliness makes the body feel threatened and insecure. Social isolation increases the chances of inflammation and viral infection. In contrast to feelings of fulfillment which strengthens the immune system and reduce illnesses. 
Read the full Psychology Today article here
.
 
Thought Leader Conversation
Social Connection in Mentoring 
with Dr. Janice Molloy
Tuesday, May 14, 2024
11am PST / 2pm EST
We will take a deep dive into the nuances of 
social connection within mentoring
, 
Janice Molloy, Ph.D.
, Associate Professor of Organizational Behavior and Human Resources Management at the 
University of Michigan-Dearborn
 College of Business, brings her expertise to the forefront, illuminating the ways in which effective mentorship can bridge the human resource management gap. Her work, rooted in extensive research and teaching, offers insightful perspectives on fostering meaningful connections and maximizing organizational potential through strategic mentor-mentee relationships. 
Register Here!
 
NCWIT 2024 Summit
Monday May 20th -
Wednesday May 22nd, 2024
Loews Kansas City Hotel
Kansas City, MO
The 2024 NCWIT Summit is where conversations lead to change is the world’s largest annual convening of change leaders focused on significantly improving diversity and equity in computing. Our own 
Lisa Fain
 
will be speaking about 
Cultivating Connections: Bridging Cultural and Identity Differences in Mentorship and Sponsorship
 
on 
Tuesday, May 21, 2024 from 11:00am-12:30pm and 1:30pm-3:00pm
. For more information visit: 
NCWIT.org/summit/2024
  
Thought Leader Conversation
Hybrid Communication in Mentoring 
with Darien Fleming
Tuesday, June 25, 2024
11am PST / 2pm EST
Darien Fleming
 is recognized for her expertise in 
hybrid communication
, a crucial component in modern mentoring relationships where individuals navigate their hectic schedules. As a learning and professional development expert, certified career coach, trainer, and former attorney, Darien brings a unique blend of skills to the evolving landscape of professional growth and communication. 
Register Here
!
  
 
Dr. Molloy recommends these three resources for more on social connection. 
This 
report from the US Surgeon General
 in which he declared an epidemic of loneliness in the United States, cites research that demonstrates that loneliness has health implications far beyond mental health.  Simply put, the document helps people understand meaningful connection and how to build organizational and community infrastructures that support meaningful connection.
The documentary 
Join or Die
 
is great for helping people understand meaningful connection and its importance. The documentary currently is in limited release, but the trailer certainly conveys the gist of the documentary, which is that forming and being part of communities is vital to our health and quality of life. If someone wants a deeper dive while waiting to see the documentary, 
this interview
 with the filmmaker is uplifting and inspiring.
Brene Brown's Atlas of the Heart
 is useful for so many reasons. There is power in being able to name emotions. Thus, while most of us relate to the emotions of glad, mad, and sad, this book describes and differentiates 87 different emotions, including concepts like connection, belonging, and fitting in.
 
“The most important things in life are the connections you make with others.”
– Tom Ford

subject: What’s Your Client’s Relationship Strategy?
body:
Free/PWYW Class Jun 27, 2024 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hi Tamara,
 
Your clients live into the challenges of relationships every day. After all, we’re 
always 
relating - to our work, to our colleagues, to everything! 
 
But often we relate from a default habituated pattern. We over-engage some relationship strategies, and perhaps leave others behind. And those patterns can create challenges. 
 
it’s likely these relationship challenges surface in your coaching sessions often…and on repeat.
 
And together, you may be partnering on goals to support how your client relates to others- perhaps to improve leadership, to listen more, or take more courageous steps. How our clients relate to their lives each day matters. 
 
But can you identify the default strategies your clients take to relationships and the impact of those approaches? Are you empowering your clients to see long-held relational patterns? 
 
In our next Free/PWYW class on June 27, we’ll share four specific relationship strategies that clients take to navigate their lives. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
REGISTER NOW 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In this pay-what-you-want, 90 minute, one session class, you’ll gain:
Insight into four key relationship strategies
Approaches for identifying these relationship strategies in clients
Awareness through a live coaching demonstration around relationship strategies
Insight into how the WE-I Profile can make seeing these strategies easy, so you can get to the coaching that matters
 
Here are the details:
 
Date: Thursday, June 27
Time: 10:30-noon PT / 1:30-3pm ET
Duration: 90 minutes
Cost:  Free or Pay what you want
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
REGISTER NOW 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The class will be recorded if you are unable to attend in person. We’ll send you the recording and the slides.
 
I hope you’ll join us. We’d love to explore this with you.
 
Take care,
 
Shani
 
 
PS - Did you know that breathwork can support your ability to be present in relationship?!  Join us on May 17, 2024, at 11 AM Pacific / 2 PM Eastern for a FREE/PWYW 
breathwork session
 exploring the theme "Embracing Presence."

subject: Do you want to use more inclusive language and not sure where to start?
body:
We'll give you The Winters Group's very own blueprint for navigating difficult conversations based on our 40 years of experience.
 
Have you ever been in a highly-charged professional conversation and didn't know 
what to say?
 
Do you want to use more inclusive language and not sure 
where to start?
 
Today more than ever, leaders and employees alike must have the skills and competencies to engage in dialogue on historically polarizing and “off-limits” topics. 
Whether leaders like it or not, employees are talking about and thinking about the issues of the day impacting employees’ level of productivity, engagement, and psychological safety.
 
In our 
Engaging in Bold, Inclusive Conversations® Facilitator Certification Program
, we give you The Winters Group's very own blueprint for navigating these conversations based on our 40 years of experience.
 
This highly interactive, skill-building learning experience will provide participants with the content, tools, and competencies necessary to strengthen their organization’s capacity to engage in Bold, Inclusive Conversations®. 
 
Our next program is in June and is already filling up! 
Register here.
 
Past participants of this program have said this about it:
"I can't remember a time (at work!) when I have 
felt so heard and seen
, and I left with an even stronger sense of clarity around 'my why.'"

. It allowed me to gain insight on myself and others (assist in personal growth) which has made me a

Thanks a
gain for great work with NBCU. I appreciate you sharing this feedback with us so LCW can continue to better client service.

From:
 Ruchelle Buenaventura <rgb51@georgetown.edu>
Sent:
 Friday, May 3, 2024 10:33:32 AM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 NBCU Immersion Summary / Invoice
Hi Tamara, 
I had a great time hosting the AAPI immersion again with NBCU! Apologies for the delayed invoice and note, it appears my first delivery failed. 
Day 2 went smoothly and we had a lot of dialogue/engagement from those who attended the session. They were especially engaged with the workplace examples, ads and modern examples of stereotypes I provided. 
There were a few requests for a refresh to the content post-session:
Joy - Refresh of social media links/AAPI people to consider. In particular, there was one person who she noticed on there who said some hateful things about the Jewish community, which she is a part of. 
Josh (DEI practitioner) - More NHPI content to be covered for future sessions, as this can lack visibility in the space. However, he had positive feedback overall. 
Recommendations for consideration:
For increasing NHPI content, potentially a separate spotlight section for pacific islander history, such as American Samoas and/or indigenous groups that were colonized. There are also some prominent examples of media. 
For the next AAPI session - perhaps updated statistics for the quizzes (some were dated from 2022). The audience is highly educated and would research some statistics - but not always the huge priority if the message comes across the same. 
Thanks!
Ruchelle
-- 
Ruchelle Buenaventura, MS, MBA
<Ruchelle Buenaventura Invoice_NBCU.pdf>

May 7, 2024
As the wave of anti-DEI backlash continues, we are starting to hear some voices calling for more balanced, less divisive conversations. We need to acknowledge that extreme views on either side are neither accurate nor productive. No, DEI will not magically make all companies better, but it will also not destroy bridges (or universities). Educating ourselves and rejecting extreme viewpoints are the best antidotes against the poison of polarization that is dominating not only DEI, but many aspects of our society.
 
– Team Aleria

subject: What Are You Asking Yourself as You Coach?
body:
Aiming the Powerful Questions at Yourself ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
What Are You Asking Yourself As a Coach?
 
 
 
 
 
 
We coaches have a quiver full of questions we ask our clients. Afterall, powerful questions are a coach’s stock-in-trade. And I’ve found that even more important than the questions we ask our clients, are the questions we ask ourselves.
 
Informed by my experience with Narrative Coaching, when I’m coaching, I hold specific questions in my mind that help me discern where the coaching wants to go. These questions honor the organic nature of the human development process and the notion that we are all always, consciously or unconsciously, shedding, searching for, shifting and sustaining aspects of ourselves.
 
As I engage with my clients, I’m asking myself the following questions:
 
What does this person want/need from me right now?
What is the purpose of the story the client is telling?
What is the crux of this situation?
 
By asking myself these questions, I can listen for what’s underneath my client’s words and discern how I can foster their deepest desires for themselves.
 
Here’s a little bit about the nature of each question.
 
What does this person want/need from me right now?
 
At first blush, you might be thinking “Well, doesn’t the client just tell you that?!”. In my experience, no. Oftentimes what we humans are most wanting is something too vulnerable to ask for.
 
At the beginning of this year, I started a coaching reflection log that I complete at the end of each session, encouraging me to think more deeply about what was going on during the session that I may have missed real time. My coaching reflection log includes each of the four questions above as well as others.
 
As I’ve answered these questions, I’ve realized that most often, my client is simply wanting to be seen, felt, heard and witnessed. They are wanting another human to experience with them a bit of what they are experiencing in their lives. They want to 
feel
 their lives. And having another empathetic human mirroring their experience allows them to process it and experience it more fully.
 
What’s the purpose of the story the client is telling?
 
Every story has a purpose, whether we are aware of it or not. The story is doing the work of forwarding our desired identity or development in some way. And the purpose of the story may or may not relate to the content of the story.
 
Here’s an example.
 
Every month or so, I share a meal with a friend. During our time together, we share what’s going on in our lives. We tell stories. 
 
The stories my friend tells are all versions of the same story. The story (told in a direct and humble way) is about how they helped, supported, rescued, tough-loved someone important to them and made their lives better. They are the hero of every story they tell. And while Joseph Campbell would tell you that we are all the heroes of our own stories, there’s more going on here.
 
I believe the purpose of those stories is to be seen as helpful, powerful, and strong, by both them and me. It tells me what they are wanting from me: affirmation of their goodness. They want that affirmation as a form of connection and nourishment. And I’m happy to do it, because I love them and affirmation is part of what love looks like.
 
What’s the crux of the situation?
 
What is the development, the change, the shift needed from within the client for them to overcome what they are experiencing?
 
I have a long time coaching client who has been some form of miserable most of the time we’ve worked together. Much of the source of his misery relates to (almost) nothing being good enough for him (including him). He has a bar for excellence that requires near perfection. And it sucks the joy out of his life.
 
The crux of the issue, what this moment of his life is asking of him, is acceptance. Acceptance of who and what is. Accepting his employees as they are - smart and capable - and not as smart or capable as he is. (He’s extremely smart and capable). This client is leaning into accepting himself, his employees, his clients and their performance, as they are, as it is, to allow himself to experience more joy.
 
As you go into your next coaching session, consider asking yourself these three questions. See how they help you both zoom out to get more perspective on what’s wanting to happen and zoom in to see into your client. Those powerful questions that you know so well will always prove useful. And perhaps asking yourself these questions and others will make your coaching even more powerful. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Alison Whitmire
President, Learning In Action
PCC and Master WE-I Practitioner
 
 
 
Alison Whitmire
President, Learning In Action
PCC and Master WE-I Practitioner

Hi Tamara!
 
Are you passionate about fostering diversity, equity, and inclusion in today's organizations? If so, our 
DEI+ Newsletter
 is your indispensable resource.  
In this week's issue, titled 
"Beyond Compliance: Why Universal Design Is Essential for Inclusive Organizations,"
 we delve into a crucial aspect of fostering inclusivity: 
universal design
.  
Picture this: a workplace scenario where inclusivity is not just a goal but a necessity. Our newsletter opens with this scenario, illustrating why organizations must embrace universal design to truly become inclusive spaces. 
But what exactly is universal design? We break it down for you, explaining its significance and how it goes beyond mere compliance to create environments that welcome everyone, regardless of ability or background.  
Moreover, we highlight the many benefits universal design brings to organizations.  
The best part? We don't just talk the talk; we walk the walk. We will provide you with a concrete solution to the workplace scenario, outlining the exact steps the organization took to prioritize universal design. 
T
hese are the exact same steps you should adopt in your organization!
Don't miss out on this opportunity to gain invaluable insights into fostering a culture of inclusivity in your organization.

Hello Hanadi,
 
Thanks again for this morning. The client was really pleased with today’s session, they felt that it had been much more successful than the Jewish Spotlight. They had appreciated the adjustments that we had implemented on Friday. They haven’t made any decisions about next steps, they are going to wait until they process the rest of the feedback from the pilot group. However, they did agree that moving forward they want to do either a 75 minute or 90 minute version.
 
Moving forward, Andrea and or Vince will reach out to you for future sessions for the NBCU Talent Lab. By any chance, did you or your computer save the chat? If so, could you please send that over? It would be in your Zoom folder.
 
I appreciate you and your contributions. 
 
Best,
Tamara

subject: ICYMI: Our grant cycle is open for BIPOC-led nonprofits!
body:
If you have any questions about the grant process, please reply to this email TODAY. Completed proposals are due June 3.
 
ICYMI: Our grant cycle is open!
 
In case you missed it, our 2024 Live Inclusively® Actualized (LIA) grant cycle is OPEN! If you have any questions about the process, please reply to this email or send them TODAY to 
LIA@wintersgroup.com
.
 
Through LIA, we award grants to BIPOC-led nonprofit organizations that break down systemic barriers in their communities. Since 2017, we have distributed $485,000 in grants to 49 nonprofits! 
Review our request for proposals here
, and send in your questions today.
 
P.S. 
completed proposals are due June 3
, so don't wait to apply!
Learn About the 2024 Grant Cycle Here
 
Through LIA, The Winters Group, Inc., awards grants to BIPOC- (Black, Indigenous, People of Color) led 501c3 nonprofit organizations that work to break down systemic barriers in their communities. Since the founding in 2017, LIA has distributed $485,000 in grants to 49 nonprofits!
Meet our 2023 Grant Recipients!
In 2023, The Winters Group distributed a total of $100,000 in grants among eight nonprofit organizations through Live Inclusively® Actualized! These BIPOC-led organizations are all doing the work to break down systemic barriers in their communities. 
Learn more about them and the powerful work they are doing here.
Read Our 2023 LIA Annual Report Here
 
 
Don't forget that a portion of your purchase from our Live Inclusively® store goes toward LIA. With each purchase, YOU are making a difference!
Shop Live Inclusively® 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: Fwd: NBCU Immersion Summary / Invoice
body:
Hello Ruchelle,
Thanks a
gain for great work with NBCU. I appreciate you sharing this feedback with us so LCW can continue to better client service.
I want to introduce you to Andrea who is now leading LCWs relationship with NBCU. I have left LCW to focus on other projects. I look 
forward to working with in the future. 
Best,
Tamara
Get 
Outlook for Android
From:
 Ruchelle Buenaventura <rgb51@georgetown.edu>
Sent:
 Friday, May 3, 2024 10:33:32 AM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 NBCU Immersion Summary / Invoice
Hi Tamara,
I had a great time hosting the AAPI immersion again with NBCU! Apologies for the delayed invoice and note, it appears my first delivery failed. 
Day 2 went smoothly and we had a lot of dialogue/engagement from those who attended the session. They were especially engaged with the workplace examples, ads and modern examples of stereotypes I provided. 
There were a few requests for a refresh to the content post-session:
Joy - Refresh of social media links/AAPI people to consider. In particular, there was one person who she noticed on there who said some hateful things about the Jewish community, which she is a part of. 
Josh (DEI practitioner) - More NHPI content to be covered for future sessions, as this can lack visibility in the space. However, he had positive feedback overall. 
Recommendations for consideration:
For increasing NHPI content, potentially a separate spotlight section for pacific islander history, such as American Samoas and/or indigenous groups that were colonized. There are also some prominent examples of media. 
For the next AAPI session - perhaps updated statistics for the quizzes (some were dated from 2022). The audience is highly educated and would research some statistics - but not always the huge priority if the message comes across the same. 
Thanks!
Ruchelle
-- 
Ruchelle Buenaventura, MS, MBA

subject: FREE/PWYW- The Gift of Presence
body:
This is not a training, it’s an experience ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hi Tamara,
 
As coaches, one of the most valuable gifts we can offer is our full presence—not only to those we coach but also to ourselves. Presence allows us to be fully engaged, attentive, and empathetic to the needs, emotions, and experiences of others.
 
Breathwork, especially through the practice of two-stage pranayama yoga, offers a profound opportunity for us to reconnect with ourselves, and be present.  
 
Let go of any assumptions or reservations you may hold about breathwork and allow yourself to fully experience its transformative potential. Join us May 17 as we experience the power of presence through breath.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
REGISTER NOW 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This is not a training about breathwork
, it's a space to breathe, connect, and focus on yourself within a supportive community. Sessions are recorded.
 
We’d love to have you join us. 
 
 
 
Take care,
 
Alison 
 
 
 
 
 
 
If you'd like to unsubscribe from our Breathwork email marketing, please click 
here
.
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe

5208 Carlton Street • Bethesda, Maryland • 20816

subject: Navigating Civil Disobedience on Campuses
body:
You don't often get email from maria@msmglobalconsulting.com. 
Learn why this is important
"Let your life be a counter-friction to stop the machine...” ― Henry David Thoreau, Civil Disobedience
 
 
 
 
“Let your life be a counter-friction to stop the machine. What I have to do is to see, at any rate, that I do not lend myself to the wrong which I condemn.”
― Henry David Thoreau, Civil Disobedience
In his essay Civil Disobedience, published in 1849, Henry David Thoreau argued that individuals must leverage their collective power to challenge government when they believe it  engages in actions that are immoral. Thoreau believed that each citizen has a duty to stand up against unjust policies and not enable the government to lull them into inaction, thus making them agents of injustice.
Civil disobedience is grounded in the concept of nonviolent action to advocate for social change, when individuals choose to disobey a law for moral or philosophical reasons. It is intended to amplify issues that individuals or groups find unjust, and bring forth public discourse that will lead to policy change.
Dozens of colleges across the country have recently experienced student-led protests against Israel’s war on Gaza. As the protests have heated up, with activists setting up encampments and even taking over campus buildings, university leaders are struggling to determine the most effective way to respond. 
As a college student, I engaged in campus protests, and continue to be a fierce advocate for social justice, so I laud the student activists who are putting their lives and futures on the line for something they strongly believe in.
I also acknowledge there is no simple way to balance protecting students’ freedom of speech and right to protest alongside maintaining a safe environment for all.  The vast majority of student-led campus protests around the country have been peaceful, yet there have been incidents of anti-Semitic speech that have led to Jewish and Israeli students feeling targeted. There is growing concern that much of the extreme and dangerous behaviors are actually being perpetrated by individuals unaffiliated with the universities, as appears to be the case at 
UT Austin
. 
However, 
the presence of police in riot gear forcefully removing and arresting non-violent protesters
 is alarming and dangerous. For example, Columbia University’s decision to bring the NYPD onto campus escalated the temperature on campus and actually ignited dozens of protests on other campuses across the country.
Amidst the chaos, there are some signs of hope for peaceful resolution. This week, Northwestern University announced a deal that permits the continuation of campus protests. Some 
takeaways 
that other universities can learn from Northwestern:
When the encampment was established, administrators banned tents 
but did not enact the policy immediately
 so they could first engage in negotiations with the protesters.
Protesters agreed to eliminate the encampment and sound systems in order to continue their campus-wide protests through June 1.
The administration agreed to fund visiting Palestinian faculty members, give scholarships for Palestinian undergraduates, and provide a community building that can be used as a gathering space for MENA students.
In our work at MSM Global, one of our principle norms is 
acknowledging multiple realities
. We are all looking at the same situation through our individual lenses that are influenced by our emotions, ideologies, and experiences. It is easy to rush to snap judgments and actions that can potentially have severe consequences when we do not pull back to take a more holistic view of the situation. Perspective taking and deep listening are paramount to constructive dialogue and I believe play a critical role in civil disobedience.  Because the Northwestern administration and protesters were willing to come together and listen to one another’s concerns and needs, they found a path forward. Leaders across our nation’s campuses could learn from this approach. 
Maria Morukian
Founder and Chief Executive Officer
MSM Global Consulting
MSM GLOBAL UPDATES
 
April has been a whirlwind for the MSM Global Consulting team!
From enriching travel experiences to fostering meaningful connections, and driving initiatives for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) growth, we've been fully immersed in advancing our mission. As we dive into May, the momentum continues to build, promising another month filled with opportunities to make lasting impact. 
For anyone interested in bringing similar sessions to your conferences or organizations, reach out to info@msmglobalconsulting.com and let us know! 
Humane Society of the United States (HSUS) Animal Care Expo
We continue to serve the animal welfare profession in a variety of meaningful ways this month.  Maria Morukian and Jasmin Robinson will be presenting at the 
2024 Animal Care Expo
 in San Antonio, Texas. 
Seeking connections, gaining commitment: How to navigate diversity, equity and inclusion dialogues
DEI is often mischaracterized or misunderstood, and people don’t always have the tools to be able to engage in complex and emotional conversations that may arise. This learning lab will offer animal welfare leaders with tools and resources for engaging in challenging conversations around DEI in their profession. 
Effective employee retention strategies using a DEI lens
The U.S. labor force is more diverse than ever, and the next-generation workforce expects employers to be diverse, equitable, and inclusive. However, hiring managers cannot afford to overlook prioritizing DEI in their strategies. This session uses themes from our 2021 State of DEI in Animal Welfare Report to conceptualize what it takes for leaders to build a culturally responsive work environment that fosters inclusion and supports employee retention. 
 
Women In Government Relations Diversity, Equity & Inclusion Summit: Building the Community We Need | May 8-9th
Maria will be speaking at 
WGR’s 5th Annual DEI Summit 
with a session entitled “Navigating Polarization and Combatting DEI Fatigue,” which will explore the cycle of progress, polarization, and pushback in DEIA work and the impact on leaders and agents of change and identify techniques to navigate polarizing conversations, regulate emotional triggers, and speak truth in high risk situations. 
The Summit welcomes government relations professionals of all backgrounds and identities committed to advancing more inclusive advocacy and policy-making, more effective policy outcomes, and diverse leadership.
The Association for Talent Development (ATD) International Conference and Expo | New Orleans, LA
Maria will be presenting and doing a book signing at the upcoming 
ATD ICE
 in New Orleans! This event is the seminal gathering for training and talent development professionals around the globe, and this year’s theme, Recharge Your Soul, is a crucial one for all of us during these challenging times. 
Maria will be presenting a session entitled, “Breaking Through the DEI Wall.” Even the most well-trained endurance runners have found themselves hitting what is called the “wall,” when their energy suddenly bottoms out and they feel like they’ve run headfirst into a brick building. After repeated attempts to make progress for DEI only too often to face inertia, ambivalence, and hostility, anyone involved in DEI efforts (e.g. leaders, trainers, talent development professionals, DEI practitioners) may find ourselves feeling exhausted by what feel like insurmountable odds. 
How can we push past the “wall,” to surge our DEI efforts forward in the moments of greatest adversity, without causing damage to ourselves and others? This session will explore strategies to bring an endurance mindset and regimen to DEI, and equip individuals with the tools to develop the physical, mental, and emotional stamina to continue to make progress even when we hit the wall. 
Join us for this important conversation if you are attending ATD ICE this year, and come find Maria during her author meet up and book signing for 
Diversity, Equity & Inclusion for Trainers: Fostering DEI in the Workplace
. Learn more at the 
author meet-up space
! 
Culture Stew
March 27th Episode:
 Inclusive Insights: A Conversation with Dr. Carol Parker Walsh
Podcast Video Update!
 You can now watch this, and all previous Season 5 episodes on the MSM Global Consulting YouTube channel!  With her extensive experience and expertise, Dr. Carol Parker Walsh shares invaluable insights on fostering inclusive workplace cultures, overcoming resistance to DEI initiatives, and the power of coaching for professional growth. Don't miss this enriching conversation that goes beyond building time for professional growth and also encourages personal care! 
April 17th Episode: 
Empowering Mental Wellness: A Conversation with Dr. Dominique Pritchett
In this Culture Stew episode, hosts Maria Morukian and Roger Moreano chat with Dr. Dominique Pritchett, a mental wellness strategist, on themes of empowerment, identity, and resilience. Dr. Pritchett's expertise in clinical psychology and social work offers insights into navigating challenges and advocating for mental health. Tune in for valuable discussions on prioritizing wellness and overcoming adversity.
May 1st Episode: 
Cultivating Change: Embracing Growth with Veronica H. Moore
Join hosts Maria Morukian and Roger Moreano in an engaging episode of Culture Stew with Veronica H. Moore, a dedicated advocate for inclusive environments. Veronica shares insights from her varied background, highlighting the importance of well-being in driving social change and the transformative power of nature. Explore her personal journey, advocacy work, and the inspiration behind her children's book, "Rosie's Special Gift," emphasizing kindness and empathy.
Stay tuned as we wrap up Season 5! 
We will be scheduling Season 6 soon. If you would like to be a guest on Culture Stew, contact us! 
MSM GLOBAL GALLERY
Here you can find curated content of current DEI issues and events for your further exploration.
 
PEN America, an organization dedicated to protecting free speech, has a robust 
Campus Free Speech Guide
, with specific tools for protesters engaging in civil disobedience. 
The PEN America Campus Free Speech Guide offers valuable advice for students considering engaging in protests involving civil disobedience. Civil disobedience, while not protected by the First Amendment, has a rich history of effecting social change, particularly on college campuses. The guide emphasizes the importance of informed decision-making, offering tips on getting trained, being prepared for responses from authorities, and staying nonviolent. It also highlights the need to educate participants about potential risks and vulnerabilities, as well as the importance of including opportunities for support and involvement for all students. The guide provides further resources for those interested in learning more about civil disobedience and protecting free expression.
 
Beautiful Trouble
 is a website and organization dedicated to providing resources, tools, and training materials for activists and organizers involved in social movements.
The website hosts a variety of resources aimed at promoting creative activism and nonviolent resistance. Beautiful Trouble is known for its comprehensive approach to activism, which emphasizes creativity, strategic thinking, and nonviolent action. The organization collaborates with activists, artists, and educators from around the world to develop resources that empower individuals and communities to create positive social change.
Utilize the storytelling section to focus on the power of narrative and storytelling in activism. This section may include tips, case studies, and practical exercises to help activists effectively communicate their messages through storytelling.
We're waiting for you! 
Would you like to be a guest on the Culture Stew Podcast? 
Do you have a publication we can share on our newsletter or on our social media accounts? 
 
Contact us at 
CultureStew
@MSMGlobalConsulting.com

The 11 best civil rights movies of all time 
 
This article by Austa Somvichian-Clausen highlights 11 impactful civil rights movies, from thought-provoking thrillers to inspiring historical dramas, each touching on real-life struggles and triumphs. From "Harriet" to "Remember the Titans," these films capture the
essence of social justice movements and cultural shifts, leaving
viewers inspired and moved by the stories they tell.
 
10 Films and TV Shows That Tell Asian American Stories
To honor Asian American Pacific Islander Heritage Month, check out this listicle curated by Jessica Sun Li in The Dartmouth,  sharing film and television works by East and South Asian American artists. This is just a small sample of the stories and experiences that represent the vast spectrum of Asian American identity.

subject: Join Us for a Bystander Intervention Training on World Press Freedom Day
body:
You don't often get email from hello@righttobe.org. 
Learn why this is important
This session aims to empower individuals to become active bystanders and support journalists facing harassment online.  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Dear friend,
As we commemorate World Press Freedom Day on May 3rd, 
we are excited to invite you to our 
Bystander Intervention: How to be an Ally When You Witness Online Abuse training,
 which is being offered in partnership with PEN America. This specific session aims to 
empower individuals to become active bystanders and support journalists
 facing harassment online. 
 
The training will focus on Right To Be’s 5Ds of bystander intervention methodology, which provides participants with practical strategies to safely and effectively intervene in situations of online abuse. 
 
Sign Up Now
 
Today, journalists face unprecedented online abuse and intimidation, affecting their coverage and having a profound negative impact on their mental health. 
Whether you are also a journalist looking to be an ally for your colleagues, an activist, or a concerned citizen
 willing to help, your participation in this workshop can make a difference in protecting press freedom and supporting media professionals.
 
Check Out our New eLearning Program for Students
  
As part of our efforts to support journalists, 
we also just launched our new eLearning program: 
Bystander Intervention: How to be an Ally When You Witness Online Abuse for Journalism Students.
  
This free and accessible course will empower aspiring journalists with bystander intervention tools to navigate online harassment and support others. 
We encourage you to sign up and share this course with your networks. To enroll, 
please fill out this form.
 
Register for our eLearning program
 
Let's come together on World Press Freedom Day to strengthen our commitment to defending journalists' right to do their work safely. 
We look forward to seeing you there, 
With gratitude, 
Right To Be

Greetings folks!
 
As you know, my contract with LCW is complete; however, there are some remaining items with the CCLP. In summary,
 
CCLP Lesson 5: Gender has been submitted to Kelly; LCW will need 3 versions- Ubisoft, UL Solutions and Generic. Ubisoft has scheduled the launch for May 6
CCLP Lesson 6 has been submitted to Ubisoft to review, Patricia will submit a final version to Kelly when returned from Ubisoft. They have scheduled to launch June 7
LCW will need 3 versions of Lesson 6- Ubisoft, UL Solutions and Generic.
UL Solutions requested a Lesson 7 Generations (set to launch in September)- 
@Sarah Nodarse
 you will have to lead the development of this content and coordinate the design with Kelly. LCW has a rich library of generational content to draw from.
Correction needed:
In the GENERIC version of Culture & Identity, there is a reference to Ubisoft. See here:
 
As of Friday, I will no longer have access to this email address so if anyone wants to reach me please contact me at

Tamara

Hello Ranya,
 
Thanks for getting back to me on these items; I’ve just cc’d Chuck so he’s in the loop on the pricing for the Spotlight handouts.
 
For facilitation, would it be possible to give us a quote per 1 hour session? These sessions will be for several different clients so the costs will be tied to different SOW’s, and we don’t currently have confirmation on the number of sessions. And of course, once we promote the session we may have requests for additional sessions throughout the year.
 
To date, we typically pay our External Facilitators approximately $600-$750 per one hour Spotlight where there are two facilitators, which is inclusive of internal meetings and preparation. And the Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the US is co-facilitated with ally.
 
So it would be helpful if you could provide an hourly rate (inclusive of meetings and preparation) and a separate cost to review the content as a SME.
 
I understand this may be align with your usual facilitation rates, but we appreciate your consideration.
 
Best,
Tamara

The Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the US is a one hour session, and we have a number of clients that would like to run the session in April and May, virtually. subject: Action requested: please complete this short training impact survey
body:
You don't often get email from training@righttobe.org. 
Learn why this is important
Dear friends,
Six months ago you attended a BI Antisemitism training with Right To Be. Thank you for joining us!
We are writing with a favor: can you help us gauge the impact of our training six months later by completing a short survey? If so, 
Click here
.
As a reminder, here are some additional resources to help you continue your learning:
Read: I”ve Got Your Back: The Indispensable Guide to Bystander Intervention by Jorge Arteaga and Emily May
Attend: additional free trainings, sign up for one today
Share: your story of harassment
. Whether it is online, in public, or at work, our anonymous storytelling platform can support your healing process while showing the world that harassment is never OK. (hyperlink)
If you are interested in another training personalized for your workplace, contact us 
here
.
Thanks again for completing the impact survey!
Best,
The Team at Right To Be

subject: CCLP Content
body:
Greetings folks!
 
As you know, my contract with LCW is complete; however, there are some remaining items with the CCLP. In summary,
 
CCLP Lesson 5: Gender has been submitted to Kelly; LCW will need 3 versions- Ubisoft, UL Solutions and Generic. Ubisoft has scheduled the launch for May 6
CCLP Lesson 6 has been submitted to Ubisoft to review, Patricia will submit a final version to Kelly when returned from Ubisoft. They have scheduled to launch June 7
LCW will need 3 versions of Lesson 6- Ubisoft, UL Solutions and Generic.
UL Solutions requested a Lesson 7 Generations (set to launch in September)- 
@Sarah Nodarse
 you will have to lead the development of this content and coordinate the design with Kelly. LCW has a rich library of generational content to draw from.
Correction needed:
In the GENERIC version of Culture & Identity, there is a reference to Ubisoft. See here:
 
As of Friday, I will no longer have access to this email address so if anyone wants to reach me please contact me at 
tamara@tamarathorpe.com
 
Best,
Tamara
