subject: Use Dropbox Replay and get your creative team together
body:
You don't often get email from no-reply@em-s.dropbox.com. 
Learn why this is important
Fast-forward your video, image, and audio project collaboration with Replay.
 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
Unite your creative team—no travel required
Replay makes collaborating on audio, video, and image projects a breeze—even when reviewers don’t have Dropbox. Centralize your creative reviews, gather feedback faster, and stay aligned the whole way through.
Try Replay
Try it with your team: Add media to Replay
To add audio, video, or image files to Replay:
Sign in
 for free with your existing Dropbox account.
If this is your first time signing in, you’ll see a demo video—click the back arrow in the top left to get to the Workspace.
From the Workspace, click “Add files” and choose where to import your media from. 
That’s it!
Learn how
Review together in real time
Bring your team together with live review. Watch, mark up, and comment on the same video, image, or audio file in Replay—like you’re all in the same room, no matter where collaborators are located.
Find out more
 
 
 
This email was sent to t.thorpe@lcwmail.com 
Want to stop getting emails from Dropbox? 
Unsubscribe
 
Dropbox, Inc., PO Box 77767, San Francisco, CA 94107

subject: Join us for FREE May 10th for an exploration of the power of Surrender!
body:
Discover new possibilities for growth and connection ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hi Tamara,
 
As coaches, we're continually guiding ourselves and our clients through the ever-changing currents of growth and transformation. Surrender invites us to release control, embrace vulnerability, and trust in the natural unfolding of life's journey. 
 
Join us May 10 for 
Together at Home
, as we explore the theme of Surrender. Together, from the comfort of our homes, we’ll dive into what surrender means for us, our coaching and our lives, asking ourselves the questions:  
 
What am I wanting to surrender as a coach?
What is the possibility that creates for me?
 
Class:
 Together at Home
Theme:
 
Surrender
Date:
 Friday, May 10, 2024
Time:
 11:30 am PT / 2:30 pm ET
Duration:
 60 minutes
Cost:
 FREE
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
SAVE YOUR SEAT 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
I hope to see you there,
 
Alison Whitmire

here
.

subject: Dr. Shirley Davis on Living Beyond ‘What If’
body:
Listen in to this podcast with Dr. Shirley Davis on why it’s never too late to move toward fulfilling your dreams and living your destiny
 
Listen to The Inclusion Solution LIVE Podcast Here
 
Dr. Shirley Davis on Living Beyond ‘What If’
 
In this third episode of the Justice for All season of The Inclusion Solution LIVE podcast, host Mary-Frances Winters, founder and CEO of The Winters Group, Inc., sits down with Dr. Shirley Davis, President of SDS Global Enterprises and author of the new book 
Inclusive Leadership for Dummies
. Listen in to learn how insights from those with 
experiences
 being overlooked and undervalued can lead to breakthroughs in inclusive leadership
, and why it’s never too late to move toward fulfilling your dreams and living your destiny. Dr. Davis also discusses her session on “Living Beyond ‘What If’ ” at the Racial Justice at Work Summit. If you missed out on attending, you'll have the opportunity to purchase access to the recorded event soon 
on our summit website
.
  
This episode of The Inclusion Solution LIVE is available now here
, wherever you get your podcasts, and you can 
access this episode on YouTube. 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States

subject: Use No Way As Way
body:
Coach as Human ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Use No Way As Way
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
“A person is a person through other persons. None of us comes into the world fully formed. We would not know how to think, or walk, or speak, or behave as human beings unless we learned it from other human beings. We need other human beings in order to be human.”
 
― 
Desmond Tutu
 
 
 
I consider myself a slow learner. It takes me a while to really “get” things: concepts, approaches, techniques. I’ve been coaching for over 20 years and one might think that by now, I’d be like “I’ve got this!”. I don’t.
 
And for the most part, I’m OK with that (though it can be uncomfortable).
 
Over the course of the last 20 years, I’ve completed two full coaching certification programs from different coaching schools, completed programs on coaching “mastery”, been certified in Narrative Coaching, taught Narrative Coaching, been certified in instruments like the WE-I Profile, certified others on it, attended a dozen or more coaching conferences, presented at some.
 
And I’m still discovering myself as a coach. 
 
My tendency (as an Enneagram 1), has been to feel like there is a “right way” to coach. A way to coach that should fit every person and every occasion. And, to a degree, this idea that there is a “right way” to coach is reinforced by the ICF (which I believe in the need for) and their coaching competencies. 
 
That said, I’ve finally determined, after so much coach training, received and given, and so many coaching hours (over 6000) and so many clients (hundreds), that there is no “right way” to coach. 
 
What drew me to this conclusion is my experience with a recent client. Unlike most of my previous clients, he is not someone who would normally get coaching. But it was strongly recommended to him, with some conditions around it, I suspect. And what an unexpected gift this client has given me.
 
Unlike my previous clients, this client is largely non-reflective. His ability to reflect on his own thinking, to take on different points of view, to connect with deeper, more vulnerable feelings, seems to be nearly non-existent.
 
Questions inviting him into other perspectives are answered largely from his own perspective. Invitations to reflect on his experience are met with surface observations. Other than anger, he has great difficulty naming his feelings. Self reflection isn’t something he had modeled for him or learned. The space that Vicktor Frankl talks about 
“between stimulus and response”
 simply doesn’t seem to exist for him.
 
After a number of coaching sessions in which I used my usual approach of inquiring into his experience, I realized - it wasn’t working. He wasn’t searching inside himself in any meaningful way or questioning himself so, of course, nothing was changing. And he was wanting to change and he had good reasons for wanting to change. He was motivated. He just couldn’t get there on his own. 
 
Of course, my first thought was that I wasn’t doing it “right”. I was off my game. I wasn’t working within his system. But I didn’t dwell on that too long (as I would have years ago).
 
Instead, I shifted my coaching style to be much more reflective of my experience. Instead of asking him to reflect, I shared my reflections. I mirrored back what I experienced of him and I offered my sense of what was happening for him and THAT is what got things moving.
 
He couldn’t reflect on his own. But when I offered my reflections, he could consider them with a degree of openness and curiosity. I took on the missing aspect of his own internal experience, offering different reflections, perspectives, empathetic responses. We took what would normally be an inner dialogue and externalized it, with me playing the reflective role. 
 
This may all seem really obvious to you - it’s not as if the idea of offering reflections and POVs as a coach is unheard of in coaching. It’s just that I’ve never experienced this degree to which it was necessary. So, it feels foreign and slightly non-coach-like. In fact, I feel certain that my current coaching of this client would not pass ICF muster. But we are making progress. Things are moving and shifting, finally.
 
As I reflect on my experience with this client, I’m reminded of Bruce Lee’s philosophy “Use no way as way”. And I’m bolstered by what he said in his book, Tao of Jeet Kune Do, “Use only that which works, and take it from any place you can find it.”
 
Ultimately, effective coaching is about what works and that can come from anywhere. And it’s the client (not the ICF) that determines what works. And often, I find that what works is discerning what the human in front of me needs from me to enter the space that allows for freedom and choice. 
 
So, if you are someone who believes there is a “right way” to coach everyone or if you believe that maybe you’re doing it “wrong”, consider using no way as way. Lean into being human with the human in front of you. Let go of what’s “right” for what works. Trust yourself.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Alison Whitmire
President, Learning In Action
PCC and Master WE-I Practitioner
 
 
 
Alison Whitmire
President, Learning In Action
PCC and Master WE-I Practitioner

subject: Spotlight Debrief
body:
Hello Hanadi,
 
Thanks again for this morning. The client was really pleased with today’s session, they felt that it had been much more successful than the Jewish Spotlight. They had appreciated the adjustments that we had implemented on Friday. They haven’t made any decisions about next steps, they are going to wait until they process the rest of the feedback from the pilot group. However, they did agree that moving forward they want to do either a 75 minute or 90 minute version.
 
Moving forward, Andrea and or Vince will reach out to you for future sessions for the NBCU Talent Lab. By any chance, did you or your computer save the chat? If so, could you please send that over? It would be in your Zoom folder.
 
I appreciate you and your contributions. 
 
Best,
Tamara

subject: RE: Jewish Spotlight REAL TIME FEEDBACK
body:
Thanks for sharing, Tamara.
 
Will you also send anything from today’s Muslim Spotlight as well? Thanks!
 
From:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, April 29, 2024 11:27 AM
To:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com>
Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] Jewish Spotlight REAL TIME FEEDBACK
 
Hello Kathy;
 
Here you go!
 
CLIENT FEEDBACK-REAL TIME DURING PILOT:
How is the Jewish community defined considering the diversity within the Jewish community? For the sake of this session, are we defining it as coming from one particular place since it is not tied to only religion? -Oh that global slide helped answer this q
Will this session discuss the Jewish connection with Israel? To not acknowledge that during the global community slide seems problematic.
There are lots of Mizrahi (middle eastern jews in LA). Could be worth talking about that one too. Will share that feedback in survey too.
Are there slides connected to what she is reading?
Glad we are addressing the left.
Could be helpful to share an example or two - especially the ones on college campuses, not to gloss over because our colleagues are mostly on the left and may not see it.
Should explain that Jews were historically restricted to certain professions; Or rather, locked out of others.
the last few slides have felt a bit long/heavy - when you pick back up, suggest bring a bit of the energy up :)
Could be worth mentioning Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel who partnered with MLK Jr. 
https://www.brandeis.edu/jewish-experience/jewish-america/2022/january/heschel-zelizer-mlk.html
 - During part about Civil Rights Act/movement
I would put an H on end of Rosh Hashanah- It's transliterated, so no wrong way, but widely accepted spelling with h at end.
There are some notable exceptions in that list of major Jewish holidays, like Sukkot and Shavuot (together with passover they form the so called "shalosh regalim")
This one is really good: 
https://www.bimbam.com/judaism-101/jewish-holidays/
The microaggressions are manageable as we have all experienced that and as Jews it isn't anything new. Its the calls to murder me and my children which is causing anxiety and depression.
 
 
All of the other chat was regular engagement from content activities.
 
Tamara
 
 
Tamara Thorpe
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW

subject: RE: TT.ANYTHING I CAN DO? : UBISOFT L 4,5,6 update requested -Closing new date
body:
Hello Patricia,
 
To complete the CCMP content for Ubisoft, you will have to coordinate and collaborate with Kelly Salek, the Instructional Designer. Before I go, Kelly will have all of the content for Lessons 5 & 6. I understand the client deadlines to launch these lessons are:
L5 May 6
L6 June 7
 
Raphaelle has provided feedback on Lesson 5; and Kelly is currently building it out in Rise. When content is built in Rise, Kelly can provide a link to “REVIEW” content and a link to a final version which his is “SCORM” file. Typically, I send Raphaelle the review link for final approval, prior to receiving and sending Ubisoft the SCORM file.
 
For Lesson 6, I’ll complete the content and send it to Raphaelle to review and approve. Once that comes back, you or someone else at LCW (such as Monica or Randy), will have to adjust the content based upon the feedback from Raphaelle. Once that is done, the content can be sent to Kelly to build in Rise, then follow the same process as described above-send Raphaelle the review link for final approval, then request the final version and SCORM link from Kelly.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions.
 
Tamara

body:

Hi friends,
 
I have fleshed out the outline for the BSC Microlearning, here is a plan for completion.
 
The outline is attached, it will have four sections. It draws heavily from the following:
-Kelly’s 
Navigating Cultures
-LCW Generic “
Race & Racism
” microlearning (sunsetted)
-CCLP 
Race and Ethnicity
 lesson for UL Solutions
-eLearining 
Managing with Intercultural Competence
 
Here is a proposed plan:
-TT: Build out detailed storyboard based on my outline (possible? Do you need more input?) – by April 26
-SN: Run storyboard by the client – Week of April 29
-Dustin: Create microlearning draft using storyboard – Week of May 6
-SN: Review draft microlearning with client – Week of May 13
-Dustin/Sarah: Finalize microlearning – Week of May 20
 
Let me know if this works for you both, and if you need more information to get started.
 
Thank you for your patience on this!
 
Sarah

body:
Hi Tamara – hope you had a great weekend.
 
The team is debriefing immediately following the session so just sent through an invite for 10-10:30am CT/11am-11:30am ET. Please let me know if that time works. We can discuss everything then.
 
Appreciate your thoughtfulness and commitment to supporting NBCU and this opportunity!
 
See you soon,
Kathy
 
 
From:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Saturday, April 27, 2024 1:12 PM
To:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com>
Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] RE: Time to Debrief Today?
 
Hello Kathy,
 
Thanks so much for the feedback. Monday, I can be available immediately following the session to debrief. I’ll hold that hour afterwards.
 
Additionally, I agree with you 100% on the feedback and we are having some additional internal discussions regarding the facilitation solutions. I also noted a few opportunities to adjust the content and alternate facilitation roles.  
 
And I was wondering if it might be a consideration for NBCU to have Joy Schwartz co-facilitate in future sessions. I don’t know how willing she would be, however, I see a huge advantage and opportunity to have an internal NBCU facilitator. We have done this before with clients, where there is a collaboration of internal and external facilitators. But again, this was just a thought I’ve had over the weekend.
 
I’ll put together those notes, as well as recommendations shared in the chat.
 
Let me know if there is anything else you need.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <
Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com
> 
Sent:
 Saturday, April 27, 2024 1:42 PM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Time to Debrief Today?
 
Hi Tamara – 
 
I’ll be in NYC next week and on east coast time. Can we try and connect Monday morning to discuss the below and a few questions/ideas we had about your transition? Also, can we schedule a quick debrief sometime Monday afternoon to debrief the session?
 
That all said, THANK YOU for getting us to these pilots!! Should have said that on Friday. 
😊
 
We’re still collecting feedback, but wanted to share a few things we’ve heard from Friday’s session that I think could help Monday’s session:
Pace/engagement – more shifts in energy/engagement is important; Ranya was noticeably reading from the slide notes and nothing visually was happening on the slides (i.e. no slide builds, visuals) for several minutes. Perhaps including more interactive facilitator moments such as a quick story, or asking for a quick comment in the chat, etc.
Content order/ transitions – some felt the content flow could be smoother (e.g. talking culture/celebration then talking stereotype threat felt disjointed); more intentional transitions would be helpful (i.e. how what is covered connects to next piece or what’s coming up, etc.)
Terms – where we mention some DEI terms like tropes, microaggression, etc., would be helpful to define (not necessarily visually, but by the facilitator)
Focus on Allyship – this is where participants wanted to hear more/spend more time; how can we ground this more in work context/examples?
 
Would be great to live chat before our Monday session. Thanks!!
 
Thank you!!
 
From:
 Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, April 26, 2024 11:06 AM
To:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <
Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com
>
Subject:
 [EXTERNAL] RE: Time to Debrief Today?
 
Possibly. With regards to the facilitation, I think Hanadi is more comfortable with the content and will have a smoother and quicker flow than Ranya. I’m meeting with Hanadi this afternoon so if you have feedback you want me to share with her for Monday, could you send it to me via email?
 
Tamara

subject: New Trainings and Other Quarterly Highlights
body:
You don't often get email from hello@righttobe.org. 
Learn why this is important
We are showing up in support for those on the frontlines at protests. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
When the customer ISN'T always right...
 | 
www.righttobe.org 
Right To Be Launches New Training For Allies!
 
 
We are thrilled to announce the recent launch of two new trainings that are being added to our curriculum to continue to help foster a culture of respect, safety and inclusivity.  
The first is the 
Bystander Intervention to Stop Antisemitic, Xenophobic, and Islamophobic Harassment training. 
In this workshop, 
co-facilitated by a Muslim and Jewish trainer, 
participants will gain an understanding of the types of disrespect that Jews and Muslims are facing right now and what allies can do to support these communities in instances of harassment.
To see upcoming training dates and register, 
visit this link.
 
The second training we've launched is the 
Bystander Intervention: Engaging Masculine-Identifying Folks as Allies training.
 This comprehensive training is designed to equip masculine-identifying folks with tools to help disrupt the cycle of hate. Through recognition of how power dynamics show up in public spaces, participants will understand how to leverage their privilege for positive change
To see upcoming training dates and register, 
visit this link. 
For more information on our next free trainings on other topics,
 check out our calendar. 
 
Supporting those on the Frontlines at Protests on College Campuses 
  
In light of recent protests on college campuses in response to war and humanitarian crisis in Gaza, 
Right To Be is offering our Conflict De-Escalation in Protest Spaces training for free.
The 60-minute interactive training teaches participants how to de-escalate counter protesters so that hate and harassment don’t escalate into violence. Using Right To Be’s Observe-Breathe-Connect methodology, this training teaches participants how to identify potential conflict before it escalates and how to assess whether intervening is the right course of action. 
Register for our upcoming training on May 1, 2024 at 1 pm ET time.
  
 
Register Now
 
 
Meet Our New Partners, Phi Iota Alpha Fraternity
To address harassment in all its forms, we’ve long known we need to build bonds with communities of key allies - which is why 
we are thrilled to announce our partnership with the fraternity 
Phi Iota Alpha.
 Stay tuned as we collaborate closely with them on an impactful roll out of our Bystander Intervention: Engaging Masculine-Identifying Folks as Allies training! 
 
We’re Tracking Hate during this Election Season
 
We recently launched our 
Hate and Hope tracker
 
designed to track stories of hate and hope online, offline and in the media. On the platform, you can also document moments of bystander intervention and support others experiencing harassment. Due to the spike of hate during this 2024 US election season, 
we are also tracking stories of election-related hate and harassment.
 When you share your story, you you not only shine a light on the problem of harassment but also help create a community of support for others.
 
Share Your Story
 
We are working to develop a map to show a complete picture of where and how hate happens, so that stakeholders have the data they need to take action. Stay tuned. 
 
Partner We’re Excited To Work With: LA vs Hate
We’re proud to highlight 
LA vs Hate
 this quarter, who have shown their commitment to supporting all people experiencing harassment and hate in their community. What is LA vs Hate? LA vs Hate is a community-centered system, led by a coalition of Los Angeles County partners such as the LA County Commission on Human Relations, and five Board of Supervisors’ Districts.
Their mission is to support all residents and communities targeted for hate acts of all kinds in Los Angeles County.
 
Right To Be is partnering with LA vs. Hate to teach bystander intervention to community members
 across different languages and backgrounds in Los Angeles. We're excited to share more updates as this partnership takes off! 
 
Supporting Journalists Experiencing Online Harassment
In honor of World Press Freedom Day on May 3rd, we will be hosting our 
Bystander Intervention to Stop Online Harassment:
How to Be an Ally When You Witness Abuse Online training,
 created in partnership with PEN America. This training will be tailored specifically to help protect journalists in instances of online harassment and empower others to be allies. 
Sign Up Here
  
 
eLearning program for Journalism Students
Continuing with our commitment to support women and gender expansive journalists,
 we are thrilled to announce Right To Be’s new eLearning program to empower the next generation of journalists.
 The  Bystander Intervention: How to be an Ally When You Witness Online Abuse for Journalism Students program is designed to teach students how to navigate and defuse instances of online harassment through proven bystander intervention strategies.  
Online harassment has deep impacts for journalists and society- we're talking about real psychological trauma, silenced voices, and marginalized perspectives being forced out of public discourse. 
 
Enroll to Our eLearning Program
 
​​​​​​Today, we want to encourage you to share this course with your networks, communities of students or aspiring journalists. To enroll,
 participants need to fill out this form.
 They will receive instructions on how to access the course. Whether you're an active voice online or simply care about preserving ethical public discourse, this course can also empower you to be an agent of positive change in our digital world. So if you are interested, we welcome you to enroll too, share your feedback with us and join the growing movement combatting online hate.
 
 
Join Right To Be's Team
We are currently
 seeking a talented Finance Manager to join the Right To Be team.
  The new Finance manager will play a pivotal role in overseeing our financial operations. The Finance Manager should have a non-profit finance background, and proven success in government grant tracking .If you want to learn more about this position and the requirements, 
visit this link. 
 
 
Calling All Schools: Join Right To Be Youth Program
Right To Be is excited to offer our powerful
 Right To Be You(th) 
curriculum
focused on
 creating an environment in which bullying is not welcomed.
 
As our President and Co-Founder Emily May states, "When we teach students to combat hate and take care of each other at a young age, we equip them with skills they'll need throughout life."
This 13-lesson program for grades 9-12 empowers students to safely intervene against bullying using our 5Ds of Bystander Intervention framework. Topics include bystander intervention scenarios, recognizing the spectrum of disrespect, and building resilience.
Schools and youth programs can apply to receive this impactful curriculum 
at no cost until Summer 2024
 as a beta partner. Visit 
Righttobe.org/youth
 
to register for an information session, join our interest list & learn more, or submit an application to become a beta partner.
Don't miss this opportunity to create a positive culture and stand against bullying!
 
Building Bonds Across Communities During International Anti-Street Harassment Week!
  
This April we were inspired by the participation and turn out for our International Anti-Street Harassment Week events, April 14th through 20th. We hosted our training to address gender-based harassment, 
Stand Up Against Street Harassment
, created in partnership with L'Oreal Paris, and uplifted actions from partners like 
Red Dot Foundation,
Chalk Back, 
Safe City,
 a
nd 
Stop Street Harassment.
 While the week has passed, these leading organizations continue their work and we encourage you to follow them! 
 
Donor Spotlight
  
​​​​​​In closing, we would like to share the testimony of a donor who has shared with us the reasons for contributing to the movement to end harassment 
"I am a recovering addict and I found on my journey that helping others brings me joy. I grow more as a person and more in my faith which calls me to donate. As a DJ I connect with crowds of all different races, creeds, beliefs and sexual orientations through music. We all just need to be more open minded and accepting of others." 
Joe Covlin, a recent donor to Right To Be shared with us. He continued: 
 
"You don't have to like everything and everyone you meet but you can treat them with respect. No matter who they are, where they come from or what they may believe, think or feel. I might not have the voice to do that Righttobe.org does" 
Any contribution, no matter how small, helps us create and build an unprecedented movement of trained, empowered, and supported members of our communities. If you also want to help us build a world filled with humanity, 
you can donate here 
Donate To Right To Be

subject: Ten Strategies for Creating an Inclusive Organization. Subscribe to DEI+ Newsletter Now!
body:
Continue reading to gain a deeper understanding of how organizations can create truly inclusive work environments ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Hi Tamara!
Last week, we took a deep dive into the crucial topic of inclusion in the workplace, shedding light on its profound impact and the stark realities of its absence.
If you found yourself nodding along to the workplace scenario we shared, you're not alone. 
Inclusion isn't just a buzzword; it's the cornerstone of thriving organizations.
But our journey doesn't stop there. As we embark on Part 2 of our series, 
Walking the Walk of Inclusion: What Organizations Must Do to Create Truly Inclusive Environments, 
we will delve even deeper into this vital subject.
In this week's issue of the 
DEI+ Newsletter
, we're going beyond the basics. We'll unveil additional benefits that organizations experience when they prioritize inclusion. From enhanced innovation to improved employee engagement, you'll discover how embracing inclusion leads to tangible, measurable outcomes.
But that's not all.
We're wrapping up our series with a bang, equipping you with 
10 proven strategies to foster a genuinely inclusive work environment
. These aren't just theoretical concepts; they're actionable steps that any organization can implement to create real change.
Whether you're a seasoned HR professional, a passionate advocate for diversity and inclusion, or simply someone who believes in the power of inclusion, this issue is for you.
Subscribe now to ensure you don't miss out on this invaluable resource. Together, let's pave the way for a more inclusive tomorrow.
 
 
👉 👉 👉 
 
CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE
.
 
 
 Inclusively yours, 
 
Luiza

subject: RE: Time to Debrief Today?
body:
Hello Kathy,
 
Thanks so much for the feedback. Monday, I can be available immediately following the session to debrief. I’ll hold that hour afterwards.
 
Additionally, I agree with you 100% on the feedback and we are having some additional internal discussions regarding the facilitation solutions. I also noted a few opportunities to adjust the content and alternate facilitation roles.  
 
And I was wondering if it might be a consideration for NBCU to have Joy Schwartz co-facilitate in future sessions. I don’t know how willing she would be, however, I see a huge advantage and opportunity to have an internal NBCU facilitator. We have done this before with clients, where there is a collaboration of internal and external facilitators. But again, this was just a thought I’ve had over the weekend.
 
I’ll put together those notes, as well as recommendations shared in the chat.
 
Let me know if there is anything else you need.
 
Tamara
 
From:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com> 
Sent:
 Saturday, April 27, 2024 1:42 PM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Time to Debrief Today?
 
Hi Tamara – 
 
I’ll be in NYC next week and on east coast time. Can we try and connect Monday morning to discuss the below and a few questions/ideas we had about your transition? Also, can we schedule a quick debrief sometime Monday afternoon to debrief the session?
 
That all said, THANK YOU for getting us to these pilots!! Should have said that on Friday. 
😊
 
We’re still collecting feedback, but wanted to share a few things we’ve heard from Friday’s session that I think could help Monday’s session:
Pace/engagement – more shifts in energy/engagement is important; Ranya was noticeably reading from the slide notes and nothing visually was happening on the slides (i.e. no slide builds, visuals) for several minutes. Perhaps including more interactive facilitator moments such as a quick story, or asking for a quick comment in the chat, etc.
Content order/ transitions – some felt the content flow could be smoother (e.g. talking culture/celebration then talking stereotype threat felt disjointed); more intentional transitions would be helpful (i.e. how what is covered connects to next piece or what’s coming up, etc.)
Terms – where we mention some DEI terms like tropes, microaggression, etc., would be helpful to define (not necessarily visually, but by the facilitator)
Focus on Allyship – this is where participants wanted to hear more/spend more time; how can we ground this more in work context/examples?
 
Would be great to live chat before our Monday session. Thanks!!
 
Thank you!!
 
From:
 Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, April 26, 2024 11:06 AM

Tamara

subject: RE: Today's client meeting
body:
Hello Hanadi,
 
Thanks for the quick connect. I’m looking forward to the collaboration. I reviewed the Shared Experiences and Common Influences, and they way there had been categorized with my understanding so I’ve adjusted the content as follows:
Shared experiences
Dedication and responsibility for elderly parents
Degrees of familiarity of the Arabic language regardless of national culture. 
Views on Islam in the U.S. through the media narrative  
Under- or mis-representation in TV/movies/ other media
Exerted efforts to fit in
Women perceived as oppressed in Islam
Perceived as ISIS sympathizer and/or terrorists
Segregated community / Silent community
 
 
Common influences
Drawing Guidance from Quran
Sanctity of Prophet Mohammad as a figure 
and role model. Reverence of Mary and Jesus.
Importance of charity in everyday life
Oneness of God as a central pillar
Modesty for men and women
Greeting each other using ‘As-Salaam-Alaikum’
Friday experience at the Mosque 
Fasting as an expression of dedication to their faith
 
I’ll send over the new version to you as well.
 
Tamara

subject: RSVP ASAP Richemont invoices
body:
Dear Chuck and Tamara,
 
The invoices for Richemont were created based on protocol of LCW:
1) 3-7 days 75%
2) 15-30 days 25%
 
April 18 Muslim spotlight was cancelled April 15 during meeting with CEO. ( TT & PC in attendance)
May 14 Jewish spotlight cancelled by Gaelle via email April 22 (cc: TT)
 
During calls yesterday Gaelle was surprised to receive invoices.
 
Upon reviewing signed docs, the signed document is proposal and does not contain the cancellation verbiage.
 
What do you suggest we do?
 
TT, has this happened before with one of the Richemont Maisons? Have they been exempt from cancellation penalties.
 
Looking for guidance so I may reach out  to client next week.
 
Best,
Patricia M Coleman 
(She-Elle-Ella)
Sr Consultant  
LCW

subject: LCW Property Return Instructions
body:
Hi Tamara,
 
A $50 stipend will be included in your final paycheck to cover the cost of purchasing the laptop box (if needed) and dropping off your LCW property to the nearest FedEx facility. If the laptop is not received within three weeks following your last day as a contractor, LCW will invoice you for the laptop/desktop’s estimated value.
 
 
Attached you can find your pre-paid FedEx shipping label. 
 
Shipping to: 
 
Alisa Kolodizner, LCW
4753 N Broadway
Flr. 2
Chicago, IL 60640
 
If you do not have a box to ship the laptop in, you can purchase one at one of their facilities (no signature required for delivery):
 
 
Please reach out if you have any questions. 
 
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Operations Manager
LCW

Hi TT –

Thanks so much, counting down the days…
RP

subject: Our Grant Cycle is OPEN for BIPOC-led nonprofits
body:
Grants are available to BIPOC-led nonprofits doing the work to break down systemic barriers in their communities
 
Our 2024 Live Inclusively® Actualized (LIA) grant cycle is OPEN! If you or someone you know is part of a BIPOC-led nonprofit, go to 
liveinclusively.org
 to get more information on how to qualify. 
Completed proposals for this year's grant cycle are due by June 3, 2024.
Learn About the 2024 Grant Cycle Here
 
Through LIA, The Winters Group, Inc., awards grants to BIPOC- (Black, Indigenous, People of Color) led 501c3 nonprofit organizations that work to break down systemic barriers in their communities. Since the founding in 2017, LIA has distributed $485,000 in grants to 49 nonprofits! 
LIA is part of The Winters Group's commitment to create an equitable world. Our mission with LIA is to break down systemic barriers that impact BIPOC communities through sponsorship and grantmaking to organizations and programs 
by and for
 BIPOC. Learn about the powerful work we were able to accomplish and the organizations we supported last year in our 
2023 Annual Report here.
Read Our 2023 LIA Annual Report Here
 
Meet our 2023 Grant Recipients!
In 2023, The Winters Group distributed a total of $100,000 in grants among eight nonprofit organizations through Live Inclusively® Actualized! These BIPOC-led organizations are all doing the work to break down systemic barriers in their communities. 
Learn more about them and the powerful work they are doing here.
 
Abide Women's Health Services
 
Children of Promise, NYC
 
Community Empowerment Fund
 
Cornerstone Corporation
 
LEAP Literacy Program
 
Proyecto Pastoral
 
RE-Center Race and Equity in Education
 
See Forever Foundation
 
Don't forget that a portion of your purchase from our Live Inclusively® store goes toward LIA. With each purchase, YOU are making a difference!
Shop Live Inclusively® 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States 
Unsubscribe

subject: The Post Most: How Columbia students sparked a revolt
body:

subject: RE: ThompsonHine Cancellation
body:
No, it was 100% them – BUT…
 
RP and I were both on a call with them, it was a Thursday. I clearly heard the client say on this call that they were postponing because they could not agree on Ranya as a facilitator for the session, and they didn’t want to have the Muslim spotlight without the Jewish one so they were going to postpone BOTH sessions until we could resolve the issue of the Jewish facilitator (RP, am I dreaming this??). So I told the facilitators that the session was postponed. The next day (Friday) the client came back and said they wanted to move forward in the original time frame, so I responded that we had to check with the facilitators, as they had been released…they weren’t happy about this - in the client’s understanding, she had NOT confirmed the postponement. So, at that point, she said, we are for sure postponing. I think she was very annoyed with me. 
 
Now they have reached out and are wanting to reschedule the sessions. 
 
From:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, April 26, 2024 9:51 AM
To:
 Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>; Tamara Thorpe <t.thorpe@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: ThompsonHine Cancellation
 
That’s problematic.
So, LCW takes the revenue hit for a client’s cancellation? Was the cancellation our fault?
 
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Chief Executive Officer
LCW

+1.773.938.4285

I wanted to follow up with you on the cancellation of the Jewish Spotlight, there was a lot of confusion with the scheduling and cancellation. Ranya Verson was scheduled to facilitate and it was cancelled the Friday before so she should receive full payment for her facilitation. Can you please follow up with her, so she can invoice for her time and preparation as she is a resource we want to maintain a good relationship with moving forward.
 
Tamara

subject: It's not the words, it's what you "do".... stay hungry!
body:
You don't often get email from michellehancock@centerformentoring.com. 
Learn why this is important
It's not the words, it's what you "do".... stay authentic and stay hungry!
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
 
 
 
This month's focus on 
retention and engagement in mentoring
 brought invaluable insights from renowned author 
Dr. Beverly Kaye
, who emphasized the significance of maintaining authenticity as a mentor to keep mentees fully engaged. Her expert advice underscores the crucial balance between genuine mentorship and the active participation of mentees in fostering a productive mentoring relationship. If you missed our 
Thought Leader Conversation 
with Dr. Kaye, 
watch it here
. 
Mentor On!
The Center for Mentoring Excellence Team
 
In 
episode 11
 of our 
Thought Leader Conversation series
, Lisa Fain speaks with 
Dr. Beverly Kaye
 about 
retention and engagement in mentoring
.
Dr. Kaye, known for her numerous publications such as 
Love 'em or Lose 'em
 and 
Help Them Grow or Watch Them Go
, offers valuable insights on the significance of maintaining authenticity and a hunger for growth. Lisa and Bev delve into the transformative impact of AI on retention and engagement in mentoring. Bev also reveals one of her cherished acronyms that defines "
Mentor
".
Join us
 on 
May 14th 
when Lisa speaks with 
Janice Molloy, PhD, 
an Associate Professor at the University of Michigan about 
social connection in mentoring
.  
 
Mentoring today is a partnership between individuals of varying ages, stages, and experiences.
 
In group mentoring, individuals rely on one or more individuals to facilitate the learning of a group of mentees. Sometimes referred to as mentoring circles, facilitated group mentoring can involve diverse individuals from different parts of the organization, individuals with similar interests and experiences, or even an intact work team. 
The mentor-facilitator might periodically introduce a new topic according to a predetermined curriculum, the group might agree on topics to discuss as they become relevant, or each session might focus solely on the goals of mentees without having a topical focus. In all instances, the role of the mentor is to facilitate learning.
The mentor’s job is to ask questions to keep the dialogue thought provoking and meaningful, share personal experiences, provide feedback, and serve as a sounding board. The concept of mentoring triads or quads is a variation on this theme. As the name suggests, three or four people are involved: with one mentor and two or three mentees who all learn from one another. 
Note: If you find yourself facilitating a mentoring group or mentoring circle, you will want to make sure all members of the group are aware of their role and responsibility and have a clear sense of the purpose, desired outcomes, and plan for moving forward. Co-creating a group work plan is a good way to begin. 
How has group mentoring played a transformative role in your professional journey?
 
It's Not the Words, It's What You Do: Authenticity and Engagement in the Workplace
It’s seen over and over again, employers losing valuable talent because they don’t feel valued or understood. We are constantly told that showing employees that they are valued and appreciated makes all the difference in retaining talent, but what is most often misunderstood is the HOW. Tune into 
this recording
 where Dr. Kaye explains how to get past the "why" and 
move towards the "do"
.
 
Last week I had the honor of speaking at the 
Second Annual Racial Justice at Work Summit
, hosted by 
The Winters Group
. Justice for all is not just a pledge, it's a vision. At the summit we explored who we need to be, what we need to know, and what we need to do to make justice for all a reality. It was an inspirational few days! For more on the 2025 summit, 
click here
. 
 
Why does mentoring matter?
I had a great conversation about this topic with 
Shannon Huffman Polson
 on the Facing the Wind podcast!
Listen in
 as we discuss the importance of establishing a proper mentoring relationship and the rules that come along with it, as well as some pro tips for goal setting, career advancement, and setting up the perfect workplace.
 
 
CALL FOR CHAPTERS
Unraveling the Tapestry of Traditional, Relational and Multicultural Feminist Mentoring Frameworks
This Handbook on Mentoring Frameworks is a part of the Handbook of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion in Management - World Scientific Publishers. Dr. Rajashi Ghosh and Dr. Payal Kumar are hosting a 
Call for Chapters
, 
click here to learn more
. 
KEY DATES:
30th April, 2024 Abstract submission 
15th May, 2024: Response from editors
15th January, 2025: Final submission 
 
UPCOMING EVENTS
Visit our LinkTree
 for upcoming events
 
Thought Leader Conversation Series
Social Connection in Mentoring 
with Dr. Janice Molloy
Tuesday, May 14, 2024
11am PST / 2pm EST
 
We will take a deep dive into the nuances of 
social connection within mentoring
, 
Janice Molloy, Ph.D.
, Associate Professor of Organizational Behavior and Human Resources Management at the 
University of Michigan-Dearborn
 College of Business, brings her expertise to the forefront, illuminating the ways in which effective mentorship can bridge the human resource management gap. Her work, rooted in extensive research and teaching, offers insightful perspectives on fostering meaningful connections and maximizing organizational potential through strategic mentor-mentee relationships.
Register Here!
 
Thought Leader Conversation Series
Hybrid Communication in Mentoring
with Darien Fleming
Date TBD, June 2024
11am PST / 2pm EST
 
Darien Fleming
 is recognized for her expertise in 
hybrid communication
, a crucial component in modern mentoring relationships where individuals navigate their hectic schedules. As a learning and professional development expert, certified career coach, trainer, and former attorney, Darien brings a unique blend of skills to the evolving landscape of professional growth and communication.
Register Here!

 to share your thoughts.

subject: Have a look at what you missed on Tuesday
body:
How Belonging Impacts Wellbeing and Workplace Productivity
 
We missed you at the webinar!
 
We noticed you weren’t registered for our latest webinar, "How Belonging Impacts Wellbeing and Workplace Productivity" that covered the must-have human skills for shaping a workplace culture that creates a strong sense of belonging for everyone. We’re reaching out because we don’t want you to miss out on this valuable information relevant to your work.
 
Some key topics discussed by our Head of Client Solutions, Lucinda Quigley, and Kayleigh Broughton, Senior HRBP Talent & ED&I, Kellanova, were:
The Psychology of Belonging - understanding how belonging (or the lack thereof) in the workplace affects mental and emotional wellbeing. 
Beyond Labels – how seeing employees as individuals is crucial for creating a true sense of belonging. 
When Belonging is Broken – how to recognize the consequences and how that impacts the individual and your business. 
Getting to Better – how to transform your work culture through a holistic, systemic approach that ultimately enhances your employees’ wellbeing and productivity.  
Even though you couldn’t attend live, you can still access the full webinar recording here:
 
Watch Webinar Recording.
 
Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions after watching the webinar or if you’d like to speak to us in more detail about our services.
 
Go and watch the webinar
 
 
 
 
 
The full name of our company is Talking Talent Ltd. We are registered in England & Wales under registration number 05617899. Our registered address is Talking Talent Ltd, 60 Chiswell Street, Milton Gate, London, London EC1Y 4AG, United Kingdom

subject: Spotlight on the Muslim Community PILOT
body:
Hello Hanadi,
 
Thank you again for your incredible flexibility. The client is looking forward to meeting with you tomorrow, to learn more about you and answer any questions you might have about Monday’s pilot session.
 
As I mentioned, we have partnered with NBCUniversal for several years; however, this is our first activation with their Global Talent Lab. Tomorrow, you will be meeting Kathy Jervey who is their team lead and our partner. She’s wonderful. We are piloting both the Jewish and Muslim Spotlights with them, as their goal is to roll this out enterprise wide.
 
The pilot session will begin with a kickoff by their 
Chief Talent Officer, Cara Stein, and the group will be approximately 25-30 people that are a are a mix of individuals from the Jewish and Muslim community as well as a some of our Meet the Moment working team partners. They understand this is a small pilot to deliver on the commitment we made to provide Antisemitism and Islamophobia education. 
 
In both sessions, participants will only share with the facilitators via chat; they will not be able to chat with one another nor come off mute to share. Our goal is to finish within an hour; however, the client has held 1.25 hours on their calendars.
 
I’ll be co-facilitating with you as the cultural ally (Facilitator B); please note that the client has asked for the Myth vs Fact section to be a poll for the participants. So I’ll launch the poll immediately after the video; have them respond then turn it over to you to provide the answers. Let me know if you have any questions.
 
You will also note a change in the Intersectionality slides; the AA/Black Muslims have been made anonymous with stock photos and I’ve removed specific names from the notes. They wanted it to both align with the other cultural groups, and they don’t have a good relationship with Dave Chappelle so mention of him had to be removed. 
 
For slides 28 and 29, I think we should choose one and not have both. Do you have a preference? 
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Best,
Tamara
 
 
Tamara Thorpe
(she/her)
Principal Consultant

Subject:
 Jewish Spotlight: Context/last notes
 
Hi Tamara – here are our final notes on the Jewish Spotlight content. 
 
General context notes:
Our Chief Talent Officer, Cara Stein, will kick off the session with a few notes 
The chat responses/questions, etc. should be set to go to the facilitators only (versus being “open”)
We currently have 26 people who RSVP’d yes; they are a mix of individuals from the Jewish and Muslim community as well as a some of our Meet the Moment working team partners
They understand this is a small pilot to deliver on the commitment we made to provide Antisemitism and Islamophobia education
Everyone’s calendars are held for 1 hour, 15 min
We will be using our survey and 
@Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal)
will send you the QR code/link
 
Content notes:
Slide 3 – points on slide and notes refer to “what you say”, “share only as you are comfortable” … please be sure to frame this as” general/universal” ground rules as the chat feature is not open for this session
Slide 5: let’s 
use the alternative video
 and end at 1:18 before the text starts on screen
Slide 7 – our legal team requested that we provide context on the poll answers; see below for her verbatim notes
The poll questions could use context - #1 should include the year…the poll is from 2021 so it would have been measuring the prior 5 years; #2 doesn’t state the period either. #5 feels a little misleading in the answer because the 11,356 is of all faiths so not clear how many of those individuals are Jewish. In clicking the link it seemed like less than 1,000 but wasn’t clear to me. Not critical to change it but someone not listening closely may think that it’s 52% of 11,356.
Slide 8 – there are slightly different stats on this slide than we previously saw; I believe this is okay, but will send this for a quick legal review. Did these come from the same Pew research study? 
Okay as is
Slide 9 – this is a new slide which wasn’t included in the previous deck; we will send this for a quick legal review – 
Okay as is
Slide 21 – point on the slide does not match notes; the “SHARE” on the slide is correct; need to update notes
Slide 23 – slide should say “ask her to do it, her people are good with 
money.
”
 
Also, remove from notes “SAY: This is a real quote…” 
Slide 26 – change title slide to “Thank you” and remove everything else except for place for QR code; underneath should say: scan this QR code with your mobile phone to provide general feedback about this session.
 
Please let us know if you have any questions, thanks!
Kathy

Subject:
 Jewish Spotlight: Context/last notes
 
Hi Tamara – here are our final notes on the Jewish Spotlight content. 
 
General context notes:
Our Chief Talent Officer, Cara Stein, will kick off the session with a few notes 
The chat responses/questions, etc. should be set to go to the facilitators only (versus being “open”)
We currently have 26 people who RSVP’d yes; they are a mix of individuals from the Jewish and Muslim community as well as a some of our Meet the Moment working team partners
They understand this is a small pilot to deliver on the commitment we made to provide Antisemitism and Islamophobia education
Everyone’s calendars are held for 1 hour, 15 min
We will be using our survey and 
@Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal)
will send you the QR code/link
 
Content notes:
Slide 3 – points on slide and notes refer to “what you say”, “share only as you are comfortable” … please be sure to frame this as” general/universal” ground rules as the chat feature is not open for this session
Slide 5: let’s 
use the alternative video
 and end at 1:18 before the text starts on screen
Slide 7 – our legal team requested that we provide context on the poll answers; see below for her verbatim notes
The poll questions could use context - #1 should include the year…the poll is from 2021 so it would have been measuring the prior 5 years; #2 doesn’t state the period either. #5 feels a little misleading in the answer because the 11,356 is of all faiths so not clear how many of those individuals are Jewish. In clicking the link it seemed like less than 1,000 but wasn’t clear to me. Not critical to change it but someone not listening closely may think that it’s 52% of 11,356.
Slide 8 – there are slightly different stats on this slide than we previously saw; I believe this is okay, but will send this for a quick legal review. Did these come from the same Pew research study? 
Okay as is
Slide 9 – this is a new slide which wasn’t included in the previous deck; we will send this for a quick legal review – 
Okay as is
Slide 21 – point on the slide does not match notes; the “SHARE” on the slide is correct; need to update notes
Slide 23 – slide should say “ask her to do it, her people are good with 
money.
”
 
Also, remove from notes “SAY: This is a real quote…” 
Slide 26 – change title slide to “Thank you” and remove everything else except for place for QR code; underneath should say: scan this QR code with your mobile phone to provide general feedback about this session.
 
Please let us know if you have any questions, thanks!
Kathy

Subject:
 Jewish Spotlight: Context/last notes
 
Hi Tamara – here are our final notes on the Jewish Spotlight content. 
 
General context notes:
Our Chief Talent Officer, Cara Stein, will kick off the session with a few notes 
The chat responses/questions, etc. should be set to go to the facilitators only (versus being “open”)
We currently have 26 people who RSVP’d yes; they are a mix of individuals from the Jewish and Muslim community as well as a some of our Meet the Moment working team partners
They understand this is a small pilot to deliver on the commitment we made to provide Antisemitism and Islamophobia education
Everyone’s calendars are held for 1 hour, 15 min
We will be using our survey and 
@Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal)
will send you the QR code/link
 
Content notes:
Slide 3 – points on slide and notes refer to “what you say”, “share only as you are comfortable” … please be sure to frame this as” general/universal” ground rules as the chat feature is not open for this session
Slide 5: let’s 
use the alternative video
 and end at 1:18 before the text starts on screen
Slide 7 – our legal team requested that we provide context on the poll answers; see below for her verbatim notes
The poll questions could use context - #1 should include the year…the poll is from 2021 so it would have been measuring the prior 5 years; #2 doesn’t state the period either. #5 feels a little misleading in the answer because the 11,356 is of all faiths so not clear how many of those individuals are Jewish. In clicking the link it seemed like less than 1,000 but wasn’t clear to me. Not critical to change it but someone not listening closely may think that it’s 52% of 11,356.
Slide 8 – there are slightly different stats on this slide than we previously saw; I believe this is okay, but will send this for a quick legal review. Did these come from the same Pew research study? 
Okay as is
Slide 9 – this is a new slide which wasn’t included in the previous deck; we will send this for a quick legal review – 
Okay as is
Slide 21 – point on the slide does not match notes; the “SHARE” on the slide is correct; need to update notes
Slide 23 – slide should say “ask her to do it, her people are good with 
money.
”
 
Also, remove from notes “SAY: This is a real quote…” 
Slide 26 – change title slide to “Thank you” and remove everything else except for place for QR code; underneath should say: scan this QR code with your mobile phone to provide general feedback about this session.
 
Please let us know if you have any questions, thanks!
Kathy

body:
Thanks, Tamara.
 
As a quick follow up to a few of our points below, legal was good with the new slides. (See purple below for reference).
 
Thanks!

Sent:
 Thursday, April 25, 2024 8:44 AM
To:

 Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal) <Destiny.Gregory@nbcuni.com>; Charles, Robin (NBCUniversal) <Robin.Charles@nbcuni.com>

Best,

From:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <
Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, April 24, 2024 9:37 PM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal) <
Destiny.Gregory@nbcuni.com
>; Charles, Robin (NBCUniversal) <
Robin.Charles@nbcuni.com
>
Subject:
 Jewish Spotlight: Context/last notes
 
Hi Tamara – here are our final notes on the Jewish Spotlight content. 
 
General context notes:
Our Chief Talent Officer, Cara Stein, will kick off the session with a few notes 
The chat responses/questions, etc. should be set to go to the facilitators only (versus being “open”)
We currently have 26 people who RSVP’d yes; they are a mix of individuals from the Jewish and Muslim community as well as a some of our Meet the Moment working team partners
They understand this is a small pilot to deliver on the commitment we made to provide Antisemitism and Islamophobia education
Everyone’s calendars are held for 1 hour, 15 min
We will be using our survey and 
@Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal)
will send you the QR code/link
 
Content notes:
Slide 3 – points on slide and notes refer to “what you say”, “share only as you are comfortable” … please be sure to frame this as” general/universal” ground rules as the chat feature is not open for this session
Slide 5: let’s 
use the alternative video
 and end at 1:18 before the text starts on screen
Slide 7 – our legal team requested that we provide context on the poll answers; see below for her verbatim notes
The poll questions could use context - #1 should include the year…the poll is from 2021 so it would have been measuring the prior 5 years; #2 doesn’t state the period either. #5 feels a little misleading in the answer because the 11,356 is of all faiths so not clear how many of those individuals are Jewish. In clicking the link it seemed like less than 1,000 but wasn’t clear to me. Not critical to change it but someone not listening closely may think that it’s 52% of 11,356.
Slide 8 – there are slightly different stats on this slide than we previously saw; I believe this is okay, but will send this for a quick legal review. Did these come from the same Pew research study? 
Okay as is
Slide 9 – this is a new slide which wasn’t included in the previous deck; we will send this for a quick legal review – 
Okay as is
Slide 21 – point on the slide does not match notes; the “SHARE” on the slide is correct; need to update notes
Slide 23 – slide should say “ask her to do it, her people are good with 
money.
”
 
Also, remove from notes “SAY: This is a real quote…” 
Slide 26 – change title slide to “Thank you” and remove everything else except for place for QR code; underneath should say: scan this QR code with your mobile phone to provide general feedback about this session.
 
Please let us know if you have any questions, thanks!
Kathy

From:
 Jervey, Kathy (NBCUniversal) <
Kathy.Jervey@nbcuni.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, April 25, 2024 1:02 AM
To:
 Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal) <
Destiny.Gregory@nbcuni.com
>; Charles, Robin (NBCUniversal) <
Robin.Charles@nbcuni.com
>
Subject:
 Muslim Spotlight Edits
 
Hi Tamara – 
 
We received legal’s review on the Muslim Spotlight content and have summarized them below for updating the deck (also, included some additional edits).
 
Content notes
:
Slide 3 – points on slide and notes refer to “what you say”, “share only as you are comfortable” … please be sure to frame this as” general/universal” ground rules as the chat feature is not open for this session
Slide 5 – still need to confirm if we can use this video – 
we are okay to use the original video as is; not the edited version. Suggestions for intro of video: “Muslim celebrities / comedians answer a surprisingly tricky question” – and there are “surprising and quite shocking questions being asked”
Slide 8 – North America and not North American (appears twice on slide)
Slide 10 and 11 – no change needed, but legal noted that this is a session on Muslims in the U.S. and both of these fact/myth questions are about Europe – perhaps acknowledge this as you talk about these two facts/myths
Slide 13 – the “answer” only notes 4 countries… are these representative/are there more than 4? If not, consider changing “Many Muslim…” to “Several”
Slide 15 – in notes, add “2023” in the paragraph that acknowledges Oct. 7. “The UN has expressed concerns more than 122 journalists have been killed…. Since the conflict started in October
 2023
, so today…”
Slide 17 – still need to confirm if we can use this video, and if so, how to best position reference to the media – 
we are okay to use this video
Slide 18 – in notes, second/repeat mention of Keith Ellison has incorrect date (one mention says 2007 and the other says 199); also repeats mention of Ilhan Omar
Slide 19 – this is a new slide we need to run past legal – 
okay as is
Slide 24 – align terms on the left with the “definitions” on the right; it’s not clear that the rows align since they are in different fonts, colors and sizes
Slide 27 – on the slide, what is the source of the stat “Black Muslim Americans make up approx. 20-25% of the Muslim American population”
Slide 29 – 
on the slide, delete the last bullet and the yellow highlight reference note “lack of support or prioritization from DEI resources”
in notes, there is reference “Remember we learned at the top of the hour that people who are or are perceived as Muslim experience more hate and discrimination than any other religious group, especially in the workplace.” See legal’s verbatim note and update, and please share the source if you have one:
I’m not sure what that is referencing. The earlier slides measure relative increases and I didn’t see a specific call out to the workplace. I recommend revising to align with what was shared earlier otherwise the presenter risks losing credibility. Something along the lines of “Remember we learned at the top of the hour that there has been an increased amount of hateful and discriminatory acts against people who are or are perceived as Muslim? We see that also show up in the workplace.” Also it notes that “other forms of workplace discrimination is decreasing (gender and race)” I want to confirm they have a source for that – maybe EEOC data? Not sure what that is based on because not all discrimination is reported. Or use the data from the same study cited in the Jewish Spotlight presentation.
Slide 30 – this is a new slide and we need to run past legal – 
okay as is
Slide 34 – change title slide to “Thank you” and remove everything else except for place for QR code; underneath should say: scan this QR code with your mobile phone to provide general feedback about this session. 
@Gregory, Destiny (NBCUniversal)
 to send
 
Please let us know if you have any questions, thank you!
